title: Fast calibration, temperature, cooling fan, and retraction test
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Tried out a few torture test/calibration models out there but they all took too long to print for what I need (2.5-3 hrs vs now 10-15 mins). Designed this to calibrate my Monoprice Maker Select V2.1 (Wanhao i3), and CR-10. Definitely can see the diff!

i3 has all metal hotend with 0.5mm retraction setting.
CR-10 has original hotend (I did have MicroSwiss all metal before, but changed back) with 3.7mm retraction setting. Though, I would up it now since 3.7mm was for the all metal hotend.

The model should measure 22mm tall, with 1mm (from top-most cylinder), 3mm, 5mm and 7mm. I didn't want to calibrate based on the base, but it should measure 10mm.

Depending on the nozzle size, the 1mm measurement will probably be closer to 1.2mm for a 0.4mm nozzle.

author: sassymaker

description.text:
Hi,
this is my first attempt at constructing a bearing.
I found many designs online, but I was not satisfied with the overall strength.
I increased the wall thickness of the rings and added a appropriate cage, which holds 10 6mm softair BB's.
The inner ring consists of two pieces, which will snap together.
The inside diameter is 15mm, the outside 40mm.
Please consider that that design uses rather large tolerances, so very precise and well calibrated 3D printers may not achieve a good result.
If the fits are too tight or too loose, try adjusting the extrusion multiplier and grind excess material away.

Assembly instructions:
Grease cage with fat and place it into the outer ring
Insert the individual balls, due to the grease they should stay in place on their own
The two inner rings can now be put into the centre and pressed together. If necessary, use glue or acetone to bond the pieces.

EDIT:
Parts have been scaled up, since they were only 1/10 of the original size

title: JUUS (Juice) - Portable JUUL charger/ Pod Storage

description.text:
JUUS!

Juice is a Personal Project I figured I would share. This is designed to charge a JUUL e-cig while also allowing you to carry around your pods freely.

Parts Needed:
-JUUL Charger: $5.99 (can use the charger your JUUL came with)
https://www.juulvapor.com/shop-juul/#usb

-Dynex Portable Charger: $6-$10
https://www.bestbuy.com/site/dynex-2000-mah-portable-charger-orchid-pink/4208518.p?skuId=4208518&cmp=RMX&extStoreId=893&ref=212&loc=1&ksid=3360cc0e-85c8-4892-84b3-4a809769613c&ksprof_id=3&ksaffcode=pg252487&ksdevice=c&lsft=ref:212,loc:2&gclid=CjwKCAiAlL_UBRBoEiwAXKgW50uPLSEUmGk6ix-r_Ybuk7-8j7Yrs7WsJRkcZ5P2lc9IND_isRg0BRoC9f4QAvD_BwE

After Printing

-Once the 3 Parts are printed you need to open up the Dynex Charger and strip away any of the plastic on it so you are left with just the electronics

-Charge the battery fully and then plug your JUUL charger into the USB port on the battery

-Clear any stringing inside the body of the JUUS and then stick the battery into the tall opening on the bottom of the JUUS keeping the JUUL charger facing the JUUL slot opening on the JUUS (Will post pictures later)

-Your JUUL should now be able to slide into the JUUL slot on the JUUS and connect right to the magnet on the charger

-Cap the bottom with the "JUUS_Bot" cap (Remove the cap when its time to charge the actual battery)

-Place pods in the pod storage and then cap that off with the "JUUS_Lid" slider

Extras!

The JUUS was designed to work with the JUUL sleeves I also Designed
(Pictured on the JUUL above)

Check out the 4 different styles!
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2634745

title: A shielded case for the Red Pitaya

description.text: A case for the Red Pitaya

A shielded case for the scope/function generator instrument from
http://redpitaya.com/. The bare RedPitaya is just the board and without any shielding or protective housing - this project attempts to remedy that. All connectors are accessible from the outside, and the LEDs can be seen through a slot in the case. Also, there are some decorative arrows for 'inputs' and 'outputs' on the case. The heatsink is poking out of the case, so should be fine in normal conditions, but you might want to add a fan if you are concerned. Find latest updates here, or send pull requests:
https://github.com/hzeller/RedPitaya-Case

The shield-metal-cut.ps PostScript file is the source for the shielding. Print this on paper and glue on a thin (best tinned) iron shield metal (like from an old consumer device or something like a can with flat tinned metal, e.g. an empty paint thinner can). Check that your printer scales properly by measuring the given reference line - if that does not match, just adapt the /measured-reference-length in the PostScript file (yes, that is hand-written postscript). Use a center punch to mark the drill holes. Drill the holes - 3mm for screw-mounts, 8mm for SMA connectors and around the heatsink mount.
Now cut out the shape, if you have thin enough material, a scissor should work just fine. Bend with pliers (there are instructions in which direction on the printout). You can create a DXF file if needed (there is a Makefile on github that helps with that).
If you have a laser cutter or other means to automatically cut the shield, please let me know what the best way is to provide a file that separates the mechanical parts from the documentation text. Different color to create a separate layer ? The OpenScad file plastic-case.scad is the source for the 3D objects.
These are the case and stand-offs needed for mounting (The plastic-case.stl file is the binary result included in this distribution for easy use). The top part of the shield will be attached with plastic heat staking: place the top shield part on the case on the inside and make sure that it fits (the connection across the heatsink pokes a bit into its space, cut that out). If it fits nicely, the three plastic pins should fit through the holes and the mounting holes right and left should align with the hole in the case. Press down the metal and melt the plastic pins by pressing a soldering iron on top - let cool. Now the top shielding is permanently in place. Put a bit of electrical tape above where the jumpers are to avoid that they make accidental contact. Place the stand-offs on the bottom part of your metal shield case (gluing them in place with superglue on the metal case is a good idea, so that they don't annoy you by falling out when needed). The top spacers in the front is a bit triangular shaped, so that it is possible to glue them against the 13x2 connector .. that way, you don't have to put glue on the board itself. Place the RedPitaya in the bottom case, with the mounting holes sitting on top of the stand-offs (don't forget to remove the original standoffs that come with the RedPitaya) and adjust the SMA-connector flaps if necessary. Bend around the screw-flaps of the metal case so that they sit on the triangular shaped stand-offs on top (this might be a bit fiddely). A good technique is -- while assembly -- to have screws push up from the bottom of the case to have all assembly holes aligned. If you want to really be sure of the grounding, you might want to solder a little cable from the ground of one of the analog connectors and wrap it around the screw hole or something, but the metal contact on the SMA connectors should be sufficient (I didn't bother with the cable). Before the final assembly: the case has some diagonal flaps between the connector cutouts on the long edge. For that to fit with the bottom metal shield, you need to cut out a little notch there; see one of the pictures. Place the top of the case on top of the assembly and push 20mm M3 countersunk screws through all assembly holes. Fasten them with M3 nuts on the bottom. Done :) If you have improvements, just send a pull request to
https://github.com/hzeller/RedPitaya-Case

comments.text:
Regarding the shield connection, I made the slots in the tin plate quite narrow, so the would make good contact with the SMA connectors.
On that note, the slots in the plastic for the SMAs are a touch too narrow, and a piece broke off between the two output jacks when I screwed a cable on. I suspected that might happen.
comments.author: Kean

comments.text: I agree, the slots in the plastic might need to be a bit wider (also, since I fudged the final positions 'by sight' a they might be a bit off-center WRT to the connectors). Also, there is room to put them a tad bit closer to the base of the connector, leaving more 'screw space'. If you have improvements that work well, send me a pull request on github
comments.author: Kean

comments.text:
Just made one, and it came out great. Gluing the standoffs straight to the PCB made assembly a breeze.
Thanks heaps for the excellent design & Postscript coding (I also quite often hand code PS)
comments.author: Kean

comments.text: Thanks - I now updated the instruction text with the proper technical terms.
comments.author: Kean

comments.text:
Excellent case, I'll print mine when I get the Red Pitaya, thanks.
I read elsewhere that heat may be an issue for enclosures and the heatsink gets very hot even in free air, how is yours performing and does the PLA soften?
comments.author: Treth

comments.text: With the case around, the heat-sink settles at about 50°C (which is not much different than in free air), and the PLA printed connector going through the middle heatsink-fin is still solid, so works fine. A little fan in general might be a good idea for long-term reliability, but probably not for the sake of the case.

title: Valentine Heart Lanyard Bead for Lamp Pull, Shoelace, Pendant, Paracord

description.text:
Here is an easy to print Valentine Heart Lanyard Bead with hole sizes from 3mm to 6mm.
Use it for a jewelry bobble (3mm), lamp cord pull (4mm hole), shoelace end (5mm hole), paracord lanyard (6mm hole) or just about anything else you can think up where a cord or chain needs an end bobble. Choose the next size up from your cord diameter. Print it as oriented so the flat back side is on the build plate and you'll only need a tiny bit of support. I provided an optional back cover you can glue on to eliminate the flat surface on the back that printed against the build plate.

It takes about 1/2 hour to print and uses less than 5 grams of material (on my printer). Print them for all your sweethearts!

description.text:
This is a customziable glass bed clamp designed in OpenSCAD. It can be configured in many ways to fit different glass and printer sizes, with or without under-bed / over-glass brackets.

Currently provided STLs

Mount Anycubic Ultrabase to Tevo Tornado
  • Tornado Ultrabase Clamp Basic - Left/Right.stl:
    • A very basic version. Sufficient if glass and print bed are even (no z-wobble). Minimal supports required (for screw notch only).
  • Tornado Ultrabase Clamp Default - Left/Right.stl:
    • The default version. Adds an additional bracket below the bed for a tighter fit. Sufficient if glass and print bed are even (no z-wobble). Additional supports required.
  • Tornado Ultrabase Clamp Basic High - Left/Right.stl:
    • Basic version in high format. Adds an additional bracket on top of the glass (to keep it down). Use if print bed or glass are uneven / wobbly. Supports: Same as Basic version.
  • Tornado Ultrabase Clamp Default High - Left/Right.stl:
    • Default version in high format. Adds an additional bracket on top of the glass (to keep it down). Use if print bed or glass are uneven / wobbly. Supports: Same as Default version.
  • Tornado Ultrabase Clamp Default - Demo with Bed.stl:
    • Demo of Tevo Tornado print bed with Default mounts and Anycubic Ultrabase.

History

When I started there was no Tornado Ultrabase bracket on thingiverse (that I know of), So I took the basic idea of jasobrino66's tevo tornado clip cristal 30x30 and decided to make a customizable version that would, among others, fit the Tornado Ultrabase setup.

My initial plan was to add an option for an additional slice around the glass edge like in Sking296's Tevo Tornado Glass Bed Tensioner, but I stopped and postponed my work on this since I wouldn't use it myself due to the additional supports that would be required (most likely resulting in a bad surface quality).

After finishing the Basic and Default version, I tested both and they did the job (tight fit, no horizontal movement). I then discovered that my print bed is a bit uneven so there was a need for an additional bracket that would pull the glass down. That's when I discovered SimonFrick's newly added TEVO Tornado Ultrabase Upgrade and I copied the idea to simply increase the height of the whole bracket, making the print much easier (compared to adding only a small attachment), at the cost of some additional material and maybe some print head clearance around the bed edges (both OK for me).

The OpenSTL File

I cleaned up and documented all the basic modules and functions, but there are still too many parameters (I had to many variations in mind) so it could be a bit tricky to configure. As a result the PrintBedClamp module itself is pretty messy, especially since it's basically a box using print bed, glass and screw facsimiles to make the cutouts ... which is overkill and unnecessarily increases render time. But it works for my current use case so I left it as it is for now. Maybe sometime in the future I will rewrite this part.

remixed_from.author: ojmalik
remixed_from.title: WanHao Duplicator I3 Ratcheting Belt Tensioner modified knob

description.text:
I remixed AlexWYYC's belt tensioner so that you can use the stock bolts for mounting it. I've also included ojmalik's modified knob to make this thing complete.

Additional parts required

  • 1 M3x20mm bolt
  • 1 M3 nut
  • 1 small cable tie

Installation

It's simpler to start this process with no filament running through the hotend.

  • Remove the cover plate at back of extruder assembly with letter E stamped on it
  • Reroute wires on fan side side so that they run under the bottom smooth rod
  • Use a cable tie as shown in photo to ensure they don't rub on the smooth rod
  • The plug of your extruder stepper should also be at the bottom
    • Unfurl wire that runs to the stepper from inside where we removed the cover plate..
    • Rotate the extruder stepper 90 degrees so that the connector is now facing downwards
  • Reinstall the cover plate marked with letter E
  • Undo the 2 bolts at the back that hold the belt for moving the extruder side to side
  • Cut the cable ties holding belt onto bolts
  • Remove the steel spring
  • Install the knob onto the belt tensioner body (leave bolt loose so you can turn knob)
  • Push belt into the stationary side
  • Feed belt into knob side paying attention that it doesn't try to loop in again
  • Turn knob until belt tight
  • Tighten knob bolt so it locks into place properly

title: Micro Flying Wing for V911/F949 receiver bricks

description.text:
I designed the wings using TinkerCAD. The purpose is to use them for a micro RC flying wing.

The assembled wing is 40cm (400mm). I was able to print each wing diagonally on my Monoprice Maker Select 3d v2.1 printer that has a 200mm build plate. I covered the wings with packing tape and used foam plates to cut out winglets that I drew freehand. The control horns were scaled down (75%) from these: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:631566. The CG is just behind the box that holds the receiver brick.

I've successfully flown it, though it still needs some trimming and a better behaving tx. Update on flying: https://youtu.be/xKoQQ9WZUiY. I got a new module for my tx so no more drop outs. Adjusted controls including rates at 60/80/100.

First flight: https://youtu.be/XcJzG3stfik

author: Heybluguy

remixed_from.author: pparsniak
remixed_from.title: Smart bearing block - common lm8uu bearing block replacement

description.text:
Use the original for printing and assembly instructions. This has only a few minor experimental changes. The washers are all replaced with shoulders on the models, and a flex area is used instead of springs. This reduces tolerance though, so they need to fit almost perfect, and probably won't without some tweaking. They're quieter than linear bearings or even the IGUS bushings with the right bearings, and horrible with cheap ones.

N.b. As per discussion, the rods are bent due to the holdowns, and the Y carriage is probably bent as well, which is the cause of most of the problems with i3 Mega linear bearing/bushing issues. Use the "alt" bottom with the i3 mega, unless it's too loose.

Note: Use good bearings and these actually work very well. I got some super cheap 623ZZ bearings that almost immediately started clicking, but then tried some high rated
623-2RS bearings thinking they would be quieter at least, but they're actually silent and smooth.

When assembling, leave it loose enough to fit the rod in without force, then tighten down until there's no play.

The main drive for this model was to give a solid surface for the the hot wheels track thrid/quarter loop model (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2779107).

author: malamaker

print_settings.Notes:: Note the infill for BASE parts may be lower, but I'd use 50% for the Bolts just so they won't break as easily.

description.text:
20180214 - Print the bolts at 90%+ infill or they can break. Alternately, you can use a metal M8 bolt and nuts/washers.
20180215 - Added a thicker version of the picamMount. V2 is thicker and should be stiffer and vibrate less with movement.

I want my picam to move with the bed so I needed a place to clamp the picam mount into.

So I designed a set that swivels. Note you still need M3 bolt and nut as I can't design an M3 bolt and nut that works in plastic.

There is a installation guide STL - DONOT PRINT THIS. It's just to show you how to install the parts. The basic parts that you need can be printed from the BASESET (no brim no raft) and BOLS_N_WASHERS (brim).

I printed this in 0.1mm. The infill I used was 50% mainly for the bolts to be stronger, if you use wall of 1.2mm, the infill for the other parts may be lower.

Printer:

JGAURORA A5

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:

Note the base set can be printed without raft or brim. The bolts and washer are tiny, so if you have some bed adhesion problems, you may need a brim - only for the bolts and washer.

The threads used is M8 so in theory you could replace the bolts with any metal M8 you have. However don't over tighten at the printer insert under the bed. Only hand-tighten.

Note the infill for BASE parts may be lower, but I'd use 50% for the Bolts just so they won't break as easily.

Assembling the mount

Note that you can use regular M8 bolts and nuts - use M8x 10mm for the clamp that attach to the printer.

For the camera mount and swivel arm, use 3x M8 x 12mm or 1x M8x12mm and 1x M8x35 and M8 nuts.

Or you could use the printer bolts. I find that the printed bolts need to be printed at very high infill (90%) or they can break too easily.

description.text:
I recently learned of the re-emergence of Homestar Runner and Strong Bad's Emails.

Notes:

You may use any infill you choose, I just always tend to use 50% for all of my cookie cutters.

This is a clamping jig for cutting conduit, rods, tubes and other cylindric things. Idea is to get a precise cut by sliding the foot of the jigsaw along the guide.

It's customizable (see attached drawing):

  • pipe_diam diameter of the thing to be cut +tolerance. 26mm worked nicely for 25mm conduit. That's a pretty loose fit though. I also tried adding just half a millimeter: super tight, but hard to change work pieces.
  • angle 90 degrees for a straight cut.
  • jig_width is the distance from guide to the edge of the jig, should match distance from the edge of the jigsaw's foot to its blade -tolerance. I used a couple of millimeters of clearance: jig_width=32 for a distance of about 35.
  • jig_depth determines how deep the blade of the saw can run. Better have some clearance or cut over the edge of the workbench, like in the picture.
  • jig_length is the length of the ledger, which is used as guide. A long jig should allow for steadier cuts than short ones.
  • bolt_diam is the width of the slot in the rails, by which the jig can be attached to a workbench.
  • wall is the thickness of various things, such as the guide and the rail. The thicker the walls, the more robust the jig.
  • slope (uphill/downhill) controls the slope of the jig, one is the mirror image of the other. Perhaps for left/right-handed users, or whichever version works best for you.

When you click Open in Customizer the initial settings are the ones that were used for the attached .stl file.

It'd be fun if you'd post your makes. I think awesome things can be made by cutting tubing to precise angles. If you make something cool using the jig, please post that too! You're most welcome to upload a photo in the comment section below!

Customizer is in a bad mood: do you get the following when opening the Customizer?

/usr/local/bin/openscad/openscad: error while loading shared libraries: libCGAL.so.10: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory

There seems to be some kind of problem right now, see this thread There are really only two ways around this

  • wait for the problem to be fixed
  • Download the .scad file and run OpenSCAD locally. No have? You find everything OpenSCAD here. Truck loads of fun, highly recommended!

title: Wall mounted filament storage (with LEDs, Acoustic foam & a charging shelve)

description.text:
This is just an idea, and is quite flexible. It doesn't require a 3D printer.
If you don't need filament storage, don't make the drawer/cabinet, and move the foam closer to the wall or use it as a normal cabinet. Don't need the charging station, don't put it. Make it a speaker (not sure how will it sound behind the foam). Don't want the acoustic foam, change it with a material that you like. (wood, leather, mirror, art etc.) Don't need the light don't put the LEDs.

ATTENTION: Make sure you know what are you doing and if you are installing the electrical outlets on your own. (USB outlets might be a better choice: i.e. https://goo.gl/9VYhu3)

NOTE: If you decide to build i as a drawer it would require a two way travel drawer slide with double extension (i.e. https://goo.gl/6k3BV3), or 2 normal slides with double extension mounted to the same piece of wood each other on the opposite side (i.e. https://goo.gl/uiY1eE). If you make it as a cabinet, a normal cabinet hinge will do (i.e. https://goo.gl/96Vjrk).

title: 8mm smooth rod Z axis guides for D-Bot

description.text:
I was having issues with my Z axis moving inconsistently, and it was binding causing me to lose build height. So I decided to try something different, and change over to smooth rods for my Z axis. To change the Z axis to smooth rods, you will need the parts below.

4 8mmX500mm smooth rods (if you can get longer it is preferred)
4 LM8LUU Bearings
28 M5X12mm screws for upper and lower mounts
16 M5X10mm screws for the bed mounts
44 M5 T-Nuts (I used the drop in kind)
4 M3X12mm screws
4 M3 Nuts

If you print this, I would love to see it, please post it using the "I Made One" Button.

description.text:
2018.02.06 (edit)

A few people seems to indicate that the fitting is too tight. Print one first at +5% if you want a loose fit and can use superglue. The stock nut should extend past the top to make it turn smoother.

The original levelling knobs on the JGAURORA A5 are too small and too difficult to turn, but there's not a lot of space to grow the knob. I decided to design one to make it a little easier to level.

However it is still very small as the space is too tight.

Note also that I printed mine tight with 0.1mm clearance - this is so I don't have to use superglue. If this is too tight for you, try to scale it up by 2% and then superglue it in.

Note use a brim as the object is too small and may not stick on some beds without a brim.

I installed an x belt tensioner and i noticed the back of the x stepper bending away from the carriage due to the added tension. This brace prevents that and keeps the stepper in place, so the x belt stays aligned with the stepper teeth.

Anet A6

Cubic, 35%

Notes:

I printed this with 3 shells and 3 top and bottom layers.
It can probably do with less infill but 35% Cubic will surely hold firm.

The easiest way to install this is to put slack on your x belt so the stepper is stress free. Then first clip the lower right notch on to the carriage and then gently bend the brace a bit and push the top left notch over the acrylic plate that holds the stepper. Don't forget to re-tension your x belt afterwards.

title: Arduino Uno & Motor Shield Case for ShakeIt
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: In my continuing adventures with sim racing on a budget, I decided to add the ShakeIt mod: http://www.racedepartment.com/downloads/shakeit-diy-rumble-feedback-for-assettocorsa-codmasters-pcars-rf1-rf2-iracing.13563/ to my G25's pedals. I considered using a standard project box or a store-bought or printed case for the Arduino and motor shield, but a few weeks into waiting for my rumble motors to arrive, I decided to build my own themed case. It's meant to look like a motorsport ECU, but seeing as it had to fit over an Arduino with a stacked shield, it has the proportions of a control unit from the 1980s.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

5%

Notes:

Print the box and the base. The "rings" for the fake connectors are just for cosmetics and completely optional. The motor caps are also optional, I just thought it would be good to keep dust out of the rumble mechanisms. The motor "ring" is a spacer I found I needed to hold two rumble motors in a single clamp. All of the motor parts are sized for 25mm diameter motors, I used Xbox 360 ones.
Only the main box needs to be printed with support.
I printed everything in ABS plastic.
This was designed around the SparkFun RedBoard, not a standard Arduino Uno, so you might have to adjust the sizing and placement of the connector holes if you use another board.

The label is also completely optional, you want to print it onto sticker paper using a program that lets you print images at "actual size" (58mm x 18mm) and at a high DPI.

Hardware

This is designed to use M3 screws for mounting the board, mostly a couple really short ones (6mm long?) but also one 40-45mm long one to hold the box closed. I screwed up here because I designed this around a 3D model of the Adafruit Motor Shield V2, but then used a cheapo eBay L293 shield in my build. Both shields only have 3 of the 4 holes of the Uno mounting pattern, but the missing hole isn't the same on each board, so I couldn't actually screw my case together. It still stays together fine just friction-fit.
The other minor issue is the spaces for the m# nuts are a bit too tall. I held the nuts in with screws and then filled the gaps with hot glue so they wouldn't fall out during assembly.

Assembly

Screw the Arduino board down to the base, then attach the motor shield. Run your wiring through the hole in the main box before screwing them into the terminals. Close the box on the base, then connect the power and USB cables. I mounted my box to the pedal base with double-sided foam tape.

title: A8_Extruder_Enclosure_v6
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a total rebuild on my first remix of filament access "gate" and blower fan cover.
I have added a left side "plate" which includes ventilation slots and way to secure the extruder wires, which will help to stop them lulling the thermistor or heater block from the 20mm block.
Included in the files is the STL for the "gate". I have made this with its own air intake for the extruder fan and - because I prefer not to rely on the arm to hold it in place - I have the gate open during printing and wack the Z rods. On top I have added a "post" to hold an elastic/rubber band. I have played with "hook and eye" type fasteners...but I find a simple rubber band does the job without fuss.

To install, remove your existing add on's. You need just two screw to use with the blower fan holes to secure the assembly to the extruder carriage. You will have to fiddle teh extruder wires around the new plate and if you want to use the horseshoe fitting, fit your extruder wires - these can be locked in place by using a small zip tie. There are holes at the top for another zip tie to stop any movement.
I have also included v5 - so you have a choice of which you prefer

I will add photo's later

print_settings.Notes:: Only the fan ducts require support and only from the bed to the mounting ears.

description.text:
The HyperCube 300 X Carriage Light is a completely new X axis carriage and E3D V6 or Volcano Extruder mount for The Original Hypercube CoreXY or Hypercube 300 CoreXY 3D printers. As its name implies it is 50% lighter than the stock parts. This will allow users to run more aggressive acceleration and jerk settings for faster prints while maintaining print quality. The X Carriage Lite also centralizes the mass of the carriage around the X rods to provide better balance thus reducing the twisting in the x rods that causes scraping of the nozzle on printed during rapid Y axis movements.

There are two fan ducts options provided 1 each for V6 and Volcano heater blocks. I am working on a circular duct. I will test it shortly and will make versions available for the E3D V6 and Volcano.

title: mcHF transceiver enclosure
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is my homebrew ham project - a HF QRP transceiver. The radio consist of two boards - UI and RF, the enclosure has three parts plus the encoder knobs and buttons. Here the complete prototype in action: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KHoxoMuJop4 More project documentation and downloads at mcHF home: http://www.m0nka.co.uk Thanks for looking! 73, Chris
M0NKA

Front, middle and back panels needs to be flipped in Replicator, so the large flat side sits on the heated bed. I use 200 micron resolution to print them and takes about 4 hours per piece.  
The VFO knob and the buttons are easy to print, higher resolution would help here if you have the time.  
The trick with the small encoder knob is to use the Multiply feature of Replicator and print four the same time, this will prevent shrinking/collapsing of the thing into itself.

title: Adjustable Geeetech 3DTouch/BLTouch Sensor mount - leaves Mounting holes free for other accessories, incl. Marlin 1.1.8 for GT2560 rev A & rev A+

description.text:
Update: 26.02.2018

  • I made a little mistake in the Config File leaving the Stock(Marlin Configuration value for Esteps=500steps/mm, I changed it to 94 steps/mm. Now everything should work fine.
  • And upon request I added the Firmware with AutoBedLeveling disabled, for people who want only to upgrade to 1.1.8 and they don't have the probe, but want to use the extra features which comes with 1.1.8

Update: 11.02.2018 I modified the Github Version of Marlin 1.1.8. myself and Updated the link down below. You can search for my name throughout the firmware, every modification I made I commented "//Akos" in the line, and left the original Value as well commented out. So you know if you're interested which one I modified.

Update: 05.02.2018 I found and mounted a good fan duct which has a very strong airflow, which works perfectly with my holder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2469333
But any fan duct might work which uses the two mounting holes in the front. Recommendation for the part cooling fan to be mounted on the PWM port of your board so that the fan speed can be adjusted(automatically in your slicer software) if you need help with this, just leave a comment.

Update: 04.02.2018 IMPORTANT: If you have Quality issues as in my pictures, try to separate the three pieces and print out independently. The extrusion problems are because the many retracts between the holes and the multiple pieces.

Update: 04.02.2018 Prototype v3 is ready for download and beta-testing.
Please tell me your opinions and improvement wishes.

Update: 03.02.2018 Prototype v2 is printed, still need to make some adjustments. But is getting there...

Update: 02.02.2018: Prototype v2 almost ready. Tomorrow it will be ready for beta testing.

Hi guys, here is a sneak-peak of what I actually working on.

A 3DTouch/BLTouch sensor mount which mounts the sensor exactly to offsets X=-40, Y=0, and doesn’t cover up the mounting screws.

Why is that important?

  1. You can use the mounting screw holes for anything else(Fans, LEDs, Camera etc.),
  2. MORE IMPORTANT, that the Y axis has no eccentricity, that translates that the 3D Sensor will always be at the same height(Z Offset) with the nozzle. I had the problem with other mounts that the ZOffset changed because of the slight rotation of the X-carriage(when I changed filament) this effect is minimized because the 3DTouch turns together with the nozzle=> it will remain at the same height.

It is still work in progress, and need some testing, to do for fine tuning the dimensions.

It can be mounted directly to the Steel-Extruder-Support(see photos) for Geetech printers.

Let me guys know what do you think. And some opinions are always welcome.
Features

  • It is adjustable in height from 30mm-80mm -> just flip the sensor holder ;-)
  • If you do not have a TouchSensor, you can mount anything on the 20mm holes
  • You have everything to mount this sensor, the parts are mountable with leftover from your Printer kit
  • I used the 2x square nuts to fix the sensor to the mount
  • everything is accessible
  • the print doesn't need support, the design has a little support built in, which you must to remove after the print with a screwdriver(see photo)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Resolution:

0.200

Infill:

works any between 30-50%

Step 0. Lower the nozzle to approx Z=0 height (it will be important in Step 5.)

Step 1. Mount the extension for the X-Endstop with a ZipTie or a screw

Step 2. Mount the Touch sensor to the part with the slotted holes(if you have a long hot end, then upside down)

Step 3. Mount it on the extension part, the one in L-shape using two square nuts and 2x bolts

Step 4. Mount the whole thing to your printer.

Step 5. Adjust the height so that between Nozzle and retracted Touchsensor Tip will remain 1.5-3 mm(or from the print bed, if you followed Step 0. and lowered the nozzle.)

Step 6. Set the new Probe-Offset values in Marlin Firmware for X=-40 and Y=0

Step 6+1/2 You also need to adjust(reduce) the bed X-length so that the carriage doesn't hit the Z-Rods. You will not lose Printing space, only the nozzle will be no more outside the bed.

Step 7. Enjoy printing with a better/more accurate leveling.

For new 3DTouch users i recommend the latest Marlin 1.1.8 Firmware for the Geeetech Prusa Printers which use the GT2560 rev A, or GT250 rev A+ board follow the Instructions below.
This is not quite a step by step tutorial, only some Marlin Configuration explanation and the correct download link for the 1.1.8 Malrin Firmware for Geeetech Printers.

So here it comes:
Download the Firmware from Thingiverse "Thing Files" section or simply download the whole Thing:

I made some little modifications myself to the firmware which I would like to explain:
I've enabled :

  • Customized the two line splash boot-up screen with the texts: "Hello Maker" / "xxx's 3D Printer"

  • "About Printer Menu" - In the LCDMenu you can find there Printer statistics about your prints, printing time, successful prints etc.

  • "Babystepping Z" - you can Live-adjust the height of thenozzle during printing for getting the perfect first layer. You find it by going during an active print to: LCDMenu->Tune->Babystep Z

  • Adjusted the X, Y Probe offset for the Mounting Support(X=-40, Y=0)

  • Enabled PID Heating for the Heated BED, if you are Using the MK2a PCB Heatbed, from Geeetech, then it is Tuned for it. But I advise you to put your values in the firmware to Autotune PID use following Gcode Command: "M303 E-1 C8 S60" If you use mostly PLA with 60C-bed

For uploading this firmware you need to use the latest Arduino IDE 1.8.5

For how to update check out other tutorials, there is a bunch of them :)

Here you can edit the Two Line in Your Splash Screen - Modify as you wish I enabled Babystepping, it is not enabled by default. With Babystepping you can live-adjust the height of the nozzle to the bed(only during printing) to access it got to LCDMenu->Tune->Babystepping. Positive values rise the nozzle, negative one lower it. With this option you can get your Ideal first layer. if you want to go smoother, you can edit Babystep_Multiplicator 10, gives me good/fast control enabling the Printer Stats Menu The Support I've designed as in the description, is offset -40mm in X, and 0mm in Y. You don't need to modify these values. Only the Z-Offset. But this you can set with M851 Z-_.__ as well in terminal. For make the gap bigger between nozzle and Bed lower the value...e.g.: "M851 Z-2.90" in the terminal or for make the gap smaller(closer to the bed) go with a greater "-" value: e.g. :"M851 Z-3.10" Here are the motion values Steps/mm, Speed(FeedRate), Velocity(Acceleration). these should be fine for you if you have the T8, 2mm pitch lead screw(change DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT to { 80, 80, 400, 94} // for { X, Y, Z ,Extruder} Here you can invert the Stepper Motor direction if it goes in the wrong direction And the MOST IMPORTANT: if you have the GT2560 Rev A+ board you don't have to change anything, but if you have the GT2560 rev A board without +, you dint have the Extra Pins for the 3DTouch, and you need to mount it to the Z-max Endstop edit the SERVO0_PIN value to "32" instead of "11" in the following file: pins_GT2560_REV_A_PLUS.h

1st. Prototype looked good, was also usable, but you couldn't adjust the the height of the Probe. So back to the drawing board. Upon request, there where more types of Hotends mounted on the steel plate, so i made this version, with adjustable height, for longer Hotends. As mounting nut, I am using the square nut, it is the most stable and easiest to add to any of your project where you need mounting holes.

title: Gnarly Rambo Archim Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Gnarly Rambo Case, or, Gnarly Archim (1 or 2) Case

There are three options for front covers, Sexy, Plain, or a step file that you can make your own. If you do and want to publish it your title should include "Gnarly RA" so it can be found via search or as a remix. RA=Rambo / Archim

You also have the choice of the solid lid, or pass through lid.

The board should be mounted USB down, unless you can really tuck the power wires...

The Ultimachine Boards have not needed cooling fans in my use cases so this case has flow through cooling but a built in baffle to keep the dirt out. There is room in the lid to cut a hole for a 40mm fan for those of you that like to push your drivers to the extreme.

Makes a sexy addition to all machines including the V1 Engineering creations, MPCNC, LowRider CNC, MP3DP...

title: Mercedes Benz W168 Handbrake Pin Retainer

description.text:
This is a replacement plug for the Mercedes Benz W168, A160 A170 A190 or A210 handbrake retaining pin plug.

The handbrake has a roll pin that retains the hand brake cover. This handbrake cover must be removed to enable removal of the centre console as needed to do any interior or Selector (GRM A61) maintenance or further removal of the front console for HVAC or other work

Every time this pin is removed the plastic retainers are usually damaged beyond repair. This upload is for a replacement plug and can be used on either side of the retaining pin.

Update:

At a workmate's suggestion, Version 2 (V2) has a small slot so it could potentially be removed by a small screwdriver or pry without damage and reused for the next time. Save plastic, save time, save the environment.

description.text:
Tried out designing from a photograph. Took an image of the front bumper of a Jeep Grand Cherokee and extruded it 4 mm. I then traced out the eyes, grill, fog lights and bottom mesh and extruded down to create a recessed appearance.

Orange Jeep: solid piece with color change at 3 mm.
White Jeep 1: 0 top, 0 bottom, honeycomb infill pattern 20% for jeep_bottom, 100% for jeep_top
White Jeep 2: 5 bottom layers, 0 top layers honeycomb infill pattern, 20% infill for jeep_bottom, 100% for jeep_top

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20% on Bottom, 100% on top

Notes:

You can print this many ways. I like the see-through honeycomb grill look. 0 Top Layers, 0 Bottom layers for the bottom piece, glue together.
You can also get a neat affect by changing filament colors at 0.3. This gives the fog lamp area in the bottom color and the top color in whatever Jeep color you want.
Glue with your favorite adhesive, I used insta-set and super glue.
I took a photo from the internet and traced it out on fusion 360.

print_settings.Notes:: ((I suppose you could print it upside down and support the screw tabs instead, but that would probably use more filament and the roughness on the center tab is an accidental feature helping hold the slightly rubbery camera stand.))

description.text:
This mount holds a Logitech C525 webcam up on the "ceiling" of a IKEA LACK enclosure... or anything else you can get a few wood screws into.

I wanted something to hold the camera for use with an OctoPi but still be able to easily and quickly remove the camera when needed for videoconferencing. The dimensions aren't perfect for holding the camera foot, but I wanted to keep the rails from needing supports.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

See notes

Notes:

Designed to print upside-down relative to use; all of Slic3r, Cura, KISSLicer, and Simplify3D open it correctly.

I think this should work fine with 0.2mm layers. I printed mine with 0.1mm layers, but that's because I had been working on an overly complex/delicate version with curved spring clips. Decided that was silly and switched to the center tab support you see now, but forgot to reset the slicer. (If you want to see the curved spring clips, look at hidden elements in the FreeCAD file.)

You will need support on the center tab (build plate only is fine, in the rails, I kept it to 45-degree angles so you shouldn't need it).

((I suppose you could print it upside down and support the screw tabs instead, but that would probably use more filament and the roughness on the center tab is an accidental feature helping hold the slightly rubbery camera stand.))

Hardware needed

Post-printing, remove the support, flip it over, mark and drill pilot holes, and affix with four (4) #6 flat-head wood screws. These should be at least a quarter-inch long; longer is okay, so long as any smooth, un-threaded area is no more than 1/8" (the tab is 3mm thick).

I think a metric 3.5 screw would be about the same, but I could be wrong and you're welcome/encouraged to tweak the FreeCad file to make the size screw hole you need. Just dig way down the tree and look for a cone named "No6Countersink." That makes a hole 3.5mm radius at the top and 1.8mm radius at the bottom. If you'd rather use pan head screws, just set the top and bottom radii to your clearance. Because the fiberboard of the LACK table is flimsy, I've been using many small screws instead of fewer larger ones as I build up my enclosure.

print_settings.Notes:: This is a wood filament so that I could sand and contour both the horse and water. During the printing, I only used a 0.4mm nozzle and the darker banding seen in the photos is when the wood filament got clogged and ended up "cooking" in my hotend. I ended up ordering a hardened 0.8mm nozzle and reprinted the base with no clogging issues.

description.text:
Still Waters Run Deep is from a scan of the Still Waters horse at the Marble Arch in London that I found on MyMiniFactory.com that was remixed to have water as the base instead of just a plain block.

It is a gift to my mum for her birthday, it represents the type of man she grew me to become, with its true meaning of "a quiet or placid manner may conceal a more passionate nature"

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

25

Notes:

This is a wood filament so that I could sand and contour both the horse and water. During the printing, I only used a 0.4mm nozzle and the darker banding seen in the photos is when the wood filament got clogged and ended up "cooking" in my hotend. I ended up ordering a hardened 0.8mm nozzle and reprinted the base with no clogging issues.

Break, Sand, and reglue

I found it very difficult to sand/file/finish the wood with the water and horse together, so I actually broke the head from the water and finished it that way with 80, then 160, then 320 grit paper and filed some of the extra rough spots. Finally hot glue the the two pieces back together!

description.text: I like the headphone stand https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1675682, and made one for a friend with LED's. I didn't like that the base was open and the wiring was exposed from the bottom, so I made a simple plate to cover the bottom. Use #4 countersink screws (short ones!) to attach to the bottom. Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Infill:

Notes:

You should actually print this at the same resolution and infill that you printed the base for the stand at. Use this to cover the wires in the LED version of his base, or just as a cover to hold in a weight for the base should you decide it needs to be heavier to stand up better or something.

Also, when printing the base for the stand, add an additional 4 or 5 more layers to the bottom or use a high percentage of infill so you have something solid to put the screws in to.

I suppose if you want this thing to be as opaque as possible, do 100% infill. You might also want to find some adhesive rubber feet of some type to put on the bottom just in case your screws aren't flush with the plastic surface.
Whipped it up in 3D Builder after printing a stand and being able to get some measurements for it. This Thing isn't pretty, but it'll do the job.

author: RikkTheGaijin

description.text:
Cleaning Nozzles
PS always remove the nozzle (very carefully, of course) when it's HOT, otherwise ABS works just like a really strong glue - it's very likely something will break when unscrewing a cold nozzle.

I've tried many ways to clean out a 3D printer Nozzle - this is what I've found works best. . A word of warning - NEVER buy the carbide drill cleaners advertised, they are extremely brittle, and can easily ruin a nozzle if they break off, which I had happen before I changed to HSS cleaners.

Firstly, buy some HSS (High Speed Steel) drills, the same size as each Nozzle you use (usually 0.3mm or 0.4mm) - these are only a few dollars on eBay. The cheaper ones may not be the specified diameter, so check they fit through a clean nozzle first, and put the oversize ones away where they won't be used by mistake.

I found these drills so small they were very hard to handle, so I designed this knurled 3D printed plastic sleeve to make handling.

I alse decided to print my drill sleeves in Orange for 0.3mm & Yellow for 0.4mm - yes - the same as the resistor color code, so I can tell the size very easily. I also color code the cleaned nozzles the same way (using a TextaColor) - it makes finding a working, cleaned out, nozzle a lot easier, rather than digging out a magnifying glass for the very small writing on the nozzle.

To clean the nozzle, first drill out any plastic with a 2mm drill, do it slowly with a battery drill & don't press too hard, you just want to clean out any ABS/PLA plastic, not drill into the metal Nozzle. Then, either by hand or a small drill, clean out the nozzle tip, blow it all clean - voila - you have a perfectly clean Nozzle. PS - it's sometimes a good idea to run an m6 die over the 6mm threads, if they are really gunked up with plastic.

Solidoodle

Replacement bottom part for hummingbird feeder.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Ultimate

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Infill:

20%

This is a replacement part for the popular three-piece hummingbird feeder sold by Schrodt, Wild About Birds, Wild Bird Superstore Duncraft and probably others for $40-$50. It consists of three parts: a beautiful glass bottle reservoir for syrup (could easily last 100 years), a copper plate (won't rust, could also last 100 years) and a cheap plastic bottom that the reservior screws into and hold the whole feeder together. The plastic bottom didn't even last two years in the southern Arizona sunshine.

This is a glowing example of a great concept but piss-poor industrial/manufacturing design. When the plastic part fails, there's no replacement to be had and most folks probably throw-out all three parts. What a waste. The right solution, of course, is to manufacture all three parts to the same (100 year) life standards. Until that happens, here's a 3D printer design for a replacement bottom.

I designed this using Sketchup and have included both the STL as well as the SKP files in case you want to improve on the design. This was my first 3D printer design and I learned a lot. Designing the threaded tube for the reservoir was done manually without plugins. I hope to never have to do that again. This design eliminates some of the odd braces and protrusions found in the original part. It also has slightly thicker walls in an effort to prolong its life. Other than that, it closely follows the original parts' dimensions.

I've printed it in PLA and ABS.... the latter is probably more suitable for sunny environments.

title: Power Supply Switch Closure Tevo Tarantula
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Power supply closure with on/off rocker switch (from MCM part number 26-745) designed for use when power supply is mounted to rail using mounts from Neo_sahara (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235752). The two bolts that attach the power supply to the bottom mount will need to be 20mm for the closure to hook on to.

Parts:
2 Power supply mounts - https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2235752
In addition to the parts required for the power supply mounts you will need:
1 Rocker switch - http://www.newark.com/mcm/26-745/rocker-switches-red-illuminated/dp/38C8818?ost=26-745&scope=partnumberlookahead&exaMfpn=true&searchref=searchlookahead&ddkey=http%3Aen-US%2FElement14_US%2Fw%2Fsearch
2 20mm long bolts for the bottom mount

Instructions:
Attach mounts to vertical rail.
Insert rocker switch into closure.
Run power cords through opening at the bottom of the closure and connect following manufacturer instructions.
Attach power supply to mounts using 20mm bolts on the bottom mount.
Remove small screw in the top front of the poser supply and save to attach top of closure.
Slide closure onto the 20mm bolts and front will clip into place.
Replace screw in top attaching closure.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Prints best with front face down on the bed (no supports needed)

Assembly

1) Attach mounts to vertical rail.
2) Insert rocker switch into cover.
3) Run power cord through opening at the bottom of the cover and connect following manufacturer's instructions.
4) Attach power supply to mounts using 20mm bolts on the bottom mount.
5) Remove small screw in the top front of the poser supply and save to attach top of cover.
6) Slide cover onto the 20mm bolts and front will clip into place.
7) Replace screw in top attaching cover.
Designed in Sketch Up

It can probably work as a secondary damper if printed using flex materials.

The holes aren't exactly centered to the damper, and the shape isn't exactly the same, but it works perfectly (nothing is obstructed), and honestly you won't see it anyways so it doesn't really matter. I've included the .step file if anyone is interested in making a perfect match for the damper.

title: Lamp Clamp - Adjustable Desk Task Lamp

description.text:
This is a replacement clamp system for the v-light adjustable desk task lamp that is available on Amazon. The lamp itself is okay quality, but is definitely built cheap. The major problem I have is when extending the light upwards, it will usually fall out of the original clamp system.

This clamp version is a work in progress, but it solves the major problems with the original clamp. The new clamp system will fit tighter onto the lamp, and also has a screw hole that can be used like a set screw.

Required Hardware

  • Re-use the nut from the original clamp
  • Re-use the metal threaded L bar from the original clamp.
  • Optionally, you can use a M4 screw as a set screw. (I'm using a M4 10mm, but you probably can get away with an 8mm)

title: Ocarina Of Time Sages
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A collection of the 6 sages from The Legend of Zelda Ocarina of Time, pieced together with care from a range of sources. Elements were brought together in Tinkercad and finished in Meshmixer. Painting is not my strongest skill, but the finished figures were touched up with nail polish and Sharpie for the most part.

Rauru: Began with the pepakura model by "Xenon", textures added from papercraft PDF via http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/.

Saria: Model pulled from www.models-resource.com, details pulled from papercraft pdf by "icthus7"

Darunia: remixed from Iozo's model

Nabooru: Built from pepakura model by "Paperlegend", details built from Tinkercad shape generators

Ruto: Built from pepakura model by "Squeezycheesecake". fins generated from clipart via http://3dp.rocks/lithophane/

Impa: Base model pulled from the "Era of the Hero" version from Hyrule Warriors at www.models-resource.com. Arm position edited in tinkercad

Zelda: Model pulled from www.models-resource.com

description.text: RenatoT's high-res Mario is very well sculpted--except that it doesn't slice correctly and there are always a few missing layers causing the head to come off during or after print. I ran the model through Meshmixer (free & useful)'s "make solid" at highest accuracy. Basically, the program tried to completely re-sculpt the model as a single piece. The result is an STL very large in size but perfectly printable. IT'S ME, MARIO!!

title: Filastruder V2 Rear Cover for Stall Protection Board

description.text:
The official Filastruder V2 laser cut case does not come with a rear cover, leaving the stall protection board exposed. This cover encloses the stall protection board and its electrical connections while maintaining access to the LCD and buttons.

It attaches to the frame using the two original stall protection board mounting bolts. The stall protection board itself mounts to the cover using four M3-25mm bolts. Two button extensions should be printed and placed through the holes labeled "in" and "out" from the inside of the cover. The stall board cover goes on the back of the stall protection board to prevent any shorts from unintended metal contact.

Required Hardware:
4x M3-25 bolt
4x M3 nut

title: Raspberry Pi 3 Model B case for mounting on Cocoon Create Touch / Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

description.text:
Slimline Raspberry Pi 3 Model B case to attach to Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus and clones:

  • Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus
  • Cocoon Create Touch
  • Balco 3D Touch
  • Monoprice Maker Select

It is designed to mount the Pi what you could consider back-to-front, so that the USB and network cables hang down while keeping the power cable to the right - minimising chance of cables intefering with printing operation.

Two versions of the top are available. One with ventilation and one without.

OpenSCAD files available at the GitHub project page: https://github.com/mpfl/cct-pi-case

Printer:

Cocoon Create Model Maker

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

1. Attach to printer

Attach the top of the case to the left or right gantry using the top or bottom M3 bolts, or to the unused z limit switch mounting holes on the right with a zip tie or two.

2. Mount Pi

Place the Pi with the processor facing the printer (essentially upside-down), covered by the bottom. Use M2.5 bolts (larger bolts can damage Pi's PCB) in the four mounting holes to connect the bottom, Pi and top al together.

Using the mechanical drawings of the Pi, I was able to create a design based on where things were meant to be on the PCB.

I then printed one out and realised that Pis are not necessarily manufactured exactly as the spec, so I added some tolerance.

title: Pi Camera Light for Harbor Freight "200 Lumen LED Super Bright Flip Light"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
assembly requires soldering.

this is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2424717
changes were because i dont have any LED strip lighting segments to use for it. but harbor freight sells a LED light swithc for $4.99 (and many times free if you use a coupon (like right now))
https://www.harborfreight.com/200-lumen-led-super-bright-flip-light-63922.html
it included pretty much everything needed except for a 6v power supply (the LED uses 4 AAA batteries, something i don't want to use for this.
it has a switch with the needed resistors, 2 led strips. and some small wires (which got thrown away)

the original was modified to accommodate the switch, the longer (and brighter) LED strips.

also the 6 pegs (2 for each LED and switch) i added are taller then needed to allow you to melt them down and hold the components in place.

i have printed it and i have wired it up. and it all works.
once i finish (my glue is drying (i used e6000, and that takes a day to cure)) i will take photos and post them

Printer:

Anet a8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Dosen't Matter

Infill:

15% is enough

Notes:

pi camera front.stl requires supports, but everything else dosent.

wiring aid.stl is to allow you to mount the LEDs in the normal position so you can figure out wiring. if you plan on using them print 2

the original file uses JST connectors, but all i have is dupont connectors so i made a adapter (dupont to jst.stl) print it if you have dupont connectors and don't want to order a JST connector.

the square mounting points were very tight so i had to file them down. to get them to fit.

if the 6 pegs are too big then look for bumps and lumps and cut them off. if it still wont fit then cut them down on the sides some more. they should be a little tight.

if the leds wont seat after getting the pegs jsut right, then check the end of the mount in between the 2 wire chanels that seems to be a culprit of inhibiting seating of the leds.

the JST adapter is quite tight when seated with a connector in it. and that was after i did a lot of fine tuning (AKA filing) just feed the wires through before you crimp them, otherwise they won't fit. i dont have the skills to make it perfect for all printers.

ive been wantign to take timelapses of my prints but the lighting by my printer is poor.
i liked the original thing, but i did not like the cost (over 20 dollars for the LED other components extra)
so i was planning on going to harbor freight for some threadlock and some other tools, and i had a coupon for the LED switch for free. so i decided to see if i could make it work.

unfortunately the LEDs were taller then the original file supported. so this remix was born.

before install after install

the tools and materials you will need are

a) soldering iron
b) old soldering iron tip with a flat surface (or ultrasonic welder)
c) desoldering pump and braid
d) wire stripper
e) wire in 4 colors (i used red, black, green, and blue)
f) glue (i used e6000)
g) crimper for either JST or dupont connecters
h) JST or dupont terminals and housing
i) a light switch from harbor freight
j) a 6 volt power supply (FYI 400 mA may cause flickering)

first let's get the electronics ready

1) first begin by disassembling the light.
a) open the plastic by removing 6 screws.
b) cut the wires from the battery terminals in the middle
c) now take photos of the circuit specifically the soldering points. this is in case you need it later.
d) now using the soldering iron and desoldering pump solder everything.
e) remove all the remaining solder with the desolder braid
e2) if you are going to cave the battery contacts then this is a good time to remove the old solder.
f) set aside the 2 leds and switch assembly. (mine contains all needed components to power the LEDs from 6 volts

get the prints ready

continue once you are done printing both the front and back and any of the other parts you want.

first finish the parts
sand/file/cut the rectangular pins (on the top and bottom (and the wiring aid, if using them)) so they fit together. they should be a little tight.

sand and file the JST adapter (if using it so when there is a dupont connecter seated in it does not protrude from the top of the bottom half (otherwise it would interfere with seating the bottom and to once all wiring is done.

wiring

first let's add 2 red wires to both connectors on the switch.

other then that the rest is up to you, remember if you have the connecters too long then just re route the wires a bit to remove the slack
below is picture that shows my wiring
note i got the blue and green crossed, it didn't hurt anything. but it did prevent me from turning it on.

picture placeholder

above picture will be added later. my phone is dead and the photo is on the phone

correction

as i stated above i messed up the wiring. so i desoldered blue and green wires, and cut them short as possible.
i then ran the blue and green wires outside the case, fixing the issue.
as i did this i broke the switch so i bridged that with some solder
below is a photo showing the fix

picture placeholder

above picture will be added later. my phone is dead and the photo is on the phone

I've recently been printing using NinjaFlex (which is brilliant BTW). On angled thin walled prints, the Replicator 2 output cooling fan would sometimes push the filament to the right causing it miss the layer below. I wanted to remedy this by having the air come from both sides. My previous version of the fan duct suffered on some machines by being too low and as it was supported on one side, would hang down on the right. I realised that I could support the duct by clipping it on both sides of the carriage. I started out by making something that would clip on, then I attached it to the fan and then added the air ducts. The first attempt enclosed the heating element too much and was too low. After printing for about three hours, a PLA version of the final design started to soften in the middle which meant that the clips at the sides became loose. I reprinted it in T-Glass and for good measure, I applied some copper tape to dissipate some of the heat. The one photographed (blue) has printed continuously for 10 hours at 250 degrees (Nylon) and shows no signs of melting. It was cool to the touch when I removed it after the print. I have marked this as work-in-progress as I have only used it for a few days and it may need adjusting. Some air flow analysis would certainly help, but I'm afraid I don't have any such tools :( so I'll have to settle for the empirical approach... Unless you can help? Update
I found the airflow from the small holes was too powerful, I've produced a version with wider holes that is more gentle whilst still providing air from 3 sides. Another Update!
Fisk4 asked if I could widen it for the people who've bought the Aluminium upgrade, apparently the body is 1.5 mm wider. So I've uploaded a version for that. Don't use this unless you have the Aluminium upgrade

Remove the old fan duct by loosening the two screws on the left of the carriage and sliding it down.  
Re tighten the screws right against the fan, taking care not to over tighten them as they are inserted directly into the plastic ( they have no metal threaded inserts).  
To attach the fan duct. Hook the two clips over the right hand side of the carriage and gently push the left hand side up into the fan, make sure that the front left clip is hooked onto the carriage.  
Given the orientation of the print, the vertical columns that hold the clips could be snapped off if bent too far while attaching, I haven't broken any off, so it's reasonably robust.  
The fan duct can be removed and replaced without any screws etc.  
I've included my Replicator 2 Makerware settings in a file called TGlass.json for any one who'd like to know the print settings I used.

comments.text:
You know that you could use an adjustable voltage regulator to slow down the air flow like the LM317. You can get it at Amazon here is the link http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00K38NMVI?keywords=adjustable%20voltage%20regulator&qid=1447525570&ref_=sr_1_4&s=electronics&sr=1-4

title: Armattan Rooster "THE FINAL" XT60 and VTX antenna sma mount

description.text:
Ok boys and Girls... This is the FINAL. Print in TPU (mine at 20% infill). Things looked pretty on paper, but as the build progressed, saw some issues with the other designs I made. This uses a 10mm plastic washer on the outside, and the "toothed" sma ring on the inside.

There is a small "nub" on the bottom of the VTX hole. After attaching the SMA and aluminum supports, place it on the bottom plate and screw it down. The numb compresses on the bottom plate and SMA has less chance of rotating for the gorillas that over tighten the Antenna.

Could use CA glue as an extra mesasure for the XT connector to hold it in place, but The TPU compressed pretty well when all bolted together, may not be needed.

print_settings.Printer:: Homebuilt with particle board, fishing line and hot glue

description.text:
This corner bracket is designed to connect square tubing to make a box shape. It slides into the square tubing and has no holes to attach to the tubing, so it's a friction fit or glued in.

I designed this for use in my perpetual pendulum wave project. At the time, the only corners I could find were printed on their side, which had 2 problems:

  • They needed support and/or post-processing
  • The print layer orientation made one of the posts weak.

This design avoids both those issues. The orientation of the layers make it so that a single layer extends into all the tubes, which strengthens the part. It prints without support on my very, very homebuilt printer.

title: Oculus Rift Constellation Sensor Mount (No screws)

description.text:
This is a simple and lightweight holder for the Oculus Rift Constellation sensors I made because I needed a better design for use with double-sided adhesive pads.

It is made for use with common 30mm^2 double-sided adhesive pads, but other double-sided tape should work just as fine.
Depending on the wall, very thin double-sided tape may not work. (rough surfaces create air pockets in particularly thin tape)

The sensor is permanently set to face straight forward, with a 10° downward tilt. In my experience, it is never really necessary to change this, as the sensors have a very wide field of view.
I mount mine slightly above head height on the wall, spaced around 1.5 meters (5 feet) from each other.

A wall mounted cup that you can use for brushes, pencils, and tools.

Have fun and keep printing!

I made this 3D model to replace the glass of an Ikea Späcka (name reference in France, I don't know if the name is the same in other countries) ceiling light which had broken at my home.
This piece needs to be printed 6 times with transparent plastic and to be correctly assembled.
The end-result is different from the original design as it clearly shows the six sections with different printing orientations, but I personally find it quite decorative.
If needed, I also designed a replacement for the bracket which was broken on my own lamp - actually this original broken bracket caused the glass to fell (thankfully, nobody was under the glass when it felt !).
I use a LED light bulb. I guess it is better not to use classic incandescent light bulbs because I don't know how the plastic would handle the heat.
Don't hesitate to post pictures of your own printings of this model and tell me if it helped you ! :)

Printer Brand:

DAGOMA

Printer:

Neva

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Notes:

The piece by itself can be printed only using rafts, no support needed.
You can use different infill (17% up to 33%) settings to get different glass "textures".

Mandatory heat soldering

To assemble the glass replacement, it is mandatory to glue the pieces between them. The three studs are only for placement purpose and cannot handle the mechanical pressure.

I personally used a cheap electronic soldering Iron I quickly passed on the joint between two pieces on both sides. This allowed the piece to be solid enough.

To assemble, first glue two pieces and then a third one.
Do the same for the three other parts.
Then glue the two sub-assemblies together.

title: Woodpecker GRBL CNC machine PCB board enclosure/box

description.text:
This is box for Woodpecker grbl board, used in many Chinese CNC engravers, lasers and milling machines.

It's designed to be used with original pcb mounting holes, to stick it to aluminium profiles. It has additional space for laser module (this is the thing, that is missing in other projects), snug fit holes for power and USB input, and opening for stepper motor cables.
It's also design with ventilation holes on bottom wall and 40x40mm fan space on case closure (12V power connector for fan is already on board, two pins over the power port).
There are also holes for indicator LEDs (showing working connection for 5V (USB), 12V, 24V and USB Tx, Rx transmission).

It works perfectly with my cable chain: https://www.thingiverse.com/Saur0n/collections/sshop-cnc

title: 1970 Dodge Challenger  simplified cnc
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I took a challenge from RC_Showdown to build another model of an American muscle car. He asked me to create a simplified version of the 1970s Dodge Challenger. In return he made the 1970s Dodge Charger.

This time I added a little more complexity by using 2.5D-cnc operations, meaning that this model can't be done by a laser cutter. On the other hand I could show these cool overhanging fenders that play a great part in the charackter.

Using a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft with a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute I milled the parts from 6.3 mm beech plywood. I used 4 mm beech rods for the axles as it actually a very tiny model.

Ths stl is no intended for printing with a fdm-printer! It's for 3d viewing only.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/Toys/Cars for more toy car designs.

comments.text: Wow, nice one. I should cut all your collection some time.
