author: pasikx

title: Just Another One Mostly Printed CNC (jaoMPCNC). Laser engraver cutter XY 1m x 1m x 0.5m d25 version.

description.text:
Just Another One Mostly Printed CNC (jaoMPCNC). Laser engraver cutter XY 1m x 1m x 0.5m version. (Z coordinate is in design)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0E84UF7myyA

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hCic6l8SmYc

( detailed document are attached cnc_laser_diy_description_guidelines.docx )

Real work area is ~ 820 x 820 mm

The Idea:

The Idea is based on
C-23.5mm OD https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:724999
F-25mm OD https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:790533

All parts design was made from scratch with OpenSCAD.

Printed with ABS on my DIY 3DPrintMi based on: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:95339

Design advantages:

• More Strong construction
• Small number of parts and parts types
• Really small parts size, print time, abs amount
• Less screws and nuts
• Balanced Head Mount
• Only 2 Steppers for XY-version, (+1 stepper for XYZ version)
• Mobility
• …

Derived parts:

Dasaki Ramps 1.4 Enclosure / Box / Case https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:761806
Printrbot Simple Metal GT2 Belt Clip https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:746423
Parametric Z-axis coupler (stepper and threaded rod coupling) https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1329750
Case for the Full Graphic Smart LCD Controller https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:87250
fanless HP PS https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?1465371-Help-me-fanless-HP-PS-26-36-42A

Designed Parts (04..0F):

Part 04: 3xBearing_Ring

cnc_laser_04_3xBearing_Ring.scad
cnc_laser_04_3xBearing_Ring.stl
Quantity: 12 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 30 min Weight: 4.45 g Length 1.75: 1480.6mm
Purpose: Main housing for MR83ZZ bearing to slide over d25 tubes
Assemble guide: Push 3 x MR83ZZ bearing into the holes, fix with M3 screw and nut gently. Put 2x on every of 6x d25 1 meter tubes.

Part 05: hole_helper (not a permanent part, used only during building)

cnc_laser_05_hole_helper.scad
cnc_laser_05_hole_helper.stl
Quantity: 2 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 15 min Weight: 2.41 g Length 1.75: 802.1mm
Purpose: To achieve exactly parallel holes on both ends of a tubes
Assemble guide: Measure and cut d25 tube first. Fit 2 hole helpers on the both ends of the tube. The end of each tube shuld exectly match with hole helper. Put a tube an a horizontal surface. Drill first upper hole with 2mm drill. Insert a short 2mm nail in a hole (don’t remove hole helper). Drill the second upper hole on another end of a tube. Insert a short 2mm nail in a hole (don’t remove hole helper). Accuratly turn the tube upside down and drill both end bottom holes (currently they are on the top) with 2mm drill. Remove both nails. Remove both hole helpers. Drill a holes smoothly increasing drill sizes until you got ~10.5mm holes.

Part 06: BaseGasket

cnc_laser_06_BaseGasket.scad
cnc_laser_06_BaseGasket.stl
Quantity: 4 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 100% Time: 1 min Weight: 0.09 g Length 1.75: 31.5mm
Purpose: To fill clearance between aluminum u-profiles of the base
Assemble guide: Сombine a holes in an aluminum u-profiles of a base, insert gasket and then insert M10 threaded rod from top. Fix with M10 nut from bottom.

Part 07: FixtureRing

cnc_laser_07_FixtureRing.scad
cnc_laser_07_FixtureRing.stl
Quantity: 8 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 31 min Weight: 5.00 g Length 1.75: 1661.8mm
Purpose: 1)To fix 2 moving tubes and 2) fix rubber belts
Assemble guide: 1) Fix 4 pcs to StepperFrame_v3a (after complete assemble of GuideRoller_v3 and Stepper fixture) with M3 screws and nuts then fix to the tube with upper holes M3 screw and nut. 2) Fix to the front and back tubes near each end with upper holes M3 screw and nut.

Part 08: StepperFrame

cnc_laser_08_StepperFrame_v3a.gcode
cnc_laser_08_StepperFrame_v3a.scad
cnc_laser_08_StepperFrame_v3a.stl
Quantity: 4 pcs
Params/1: Supports: Yes, Brim: Yes (included in provided .gcode file) Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 57 min Weight: 10.12 g Length 1.75: 3366.2mm
Purpose: To fix steppers and free ends of moving tubes
Assemble guide: Insert assembled GuideRoller_v3 screws. Fix stepper on stepper end only. Fix FixtureRing.

Part 09: GuideRoller

cnc_laser_09_GuideRoller_v3.scad
cnc_laser_09_GuideRoller_v3.stl
Quantity: 8 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.15 Infill 100% Time: 14 min Weight: 0.37 g Length 1.75: 123.2mm
Purpose: To hold and guide a belts to GT2 timing pulley
Assemble guide: Fix a MR83ZZ bearing on a 32mm M3 screw with two M3 nuts. Push GuideRoller on a MR83ZZ bearing gently until stop. Insert two assembled Rollers into StepperFrame_v3a according a picture provided.

Part 0A: FixtureFrame

cnc_laser_0A_FixtureFrame.scad
cnc_laser_0A_FixtureFrame.stl
Quantity: 12 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 13 min Weight: 2.25 g Length 1.75: 746.9mm
Purpose: 1)To fix a space between each pair of 3xBearing_Rings on a static tubes 2) To hold ends of front and back rubber belts.
Assemble guide: 1)Attach two of FixtureFrame to the both bottom MR83ZZ bearing “ears” of the 3xBearing_Rings on a static tubes.2) Push FixtureFrame on the top of each FixtureRing on a ends of front and back static tubes.

Part 0B: HeadPlate

cnc_laser_0B_HeadPlate.scad
cnc_laser_0B_HeadPlate.stl
Quantity: 2 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 1h 9 min Weight: 11.22 g Length 1.75: 3730.5 mm
Purpose: Head top and bottom plates.
Assemble guide: Insert 4 M8 threaded rods into the bottom HeadPlate. Collect all 4 3xBearing_Ring symmetrically add four HeadFixers (two 2a and two 2b). Insert M8 threaded rods of bottom plate into four HeadFixers holes from bottom. Attach top HeadPlate on the top. Fix with M8 nuts from both sides. Look at the pictures provided.

Part 0C: LaserMount

cnc_laser_0C_LaserMount.scad
cnc_laser_0C_LaserMount.stl
Quantity: 1 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 1h 26 min Weight: 14.31 g Length 1.75: 4760.7 mm
Purpose: Mount Laser on a Head.
Assemble guide: Attach Laser with M3 screws. Attach LaserMount on two diagonal M8 threaded rods and fix with M8 nuts.

Part 0D: OptSensorFixture

cnc_laser_0D_OptSensorFixture.scad
cnc_laser_0D_OptSensorFixture.stl
Quantity: 2 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 27 min Weight: 2.87 g Length 1.75: 953.9 mm
Purpose: Mount Optical Endstop Sensor to M10 threaded rod.
Assemble guide: Attach Sensor with M3 screw and nut. Attach OptSensorFixture to the M10 threaded rod with two M10 nuts. According to the picture.

Part 0E: OptSensorFlag

cnc_laser_0E_OptSensorFlag.scad
cnc_laser_0E_OptSensorFlag.stl
Quantity: 2 pcs
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 7 min Weight: 0.40 g Length 1.75: 133.1 mm
Purpose: Cover IR beam of Optical Endstop sensors.
Assemble guide: Paint with black nail polish from both sides! Attach to Stepper with M3 screw Adjust to be in a middle of Optical Sensor in a zero position.

Part 0F: HeadFixer

cnc_laser_0F_HeadFixer_v2a.scad
cnc_laser_0F_HeadFixer_v2a.stl
cnc_laser_0F_HeadFixer_v2b.scad
cnc_laser_0F_HeadFixer_v2b.stl
Quantity: 4 pcs (2a + 2b)
Params/1: Supports: No Layer: 0.2 Infill 20% Time: 35 min Weight: 5.89 g Length 1.75: 1958.3 mm
Purpose: Fix .four 3xBearing_Rings together
Assemble guide: : Insert 4 M8 threaded rods into the bottom HeadPlate. Collect all 4 3xBearing_Ring symmetrically add four HeadFixers (two 2a and two 2b). Insert M8 threaded rods of bottom plate into four HeadFixers holes from bottom. Attach top HeadPlate on the top. Fix with M8 nuts from both sides. Look at the pictures provided.

Firmware:

Marlin_1.1.8_Configuration.zip - My Configuration files for Marlin Firmware

Laser PWM control is attached to D6 at Servos ramps 1.4 connector.

Laser power is controlled by:
M3 Sxxx - Laser On: xxx=0..255, 255 - max
M5 - Laser Off

Test code:

PowerTestCode.zip - Code to generate Laser power test .gcode files (windows)
TestGcode.zip - Test files to start with

CAM Software Used:

Laser GRBL 2.8.35: Vectorize mode only (without filling).

Postprocess:
Replace:
"M5 S255" -> "M3 S0"
"M3" -> "M3 S255"
"M5" -> "M3 S0"
Rename: .nc -> .gcode

Av's SVG to GCODE v 1.2.6

Preprocess:
check initial svg units (Marlin works in mm only):
Replace 'width="4in" height="3in"'

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xml:space="preserve" width="4in" height="3in" version="1.1" style="shape-rendering:geometricPrecision; text-rendering:geometricPrecision; image-rendering:optimizeQuality; fill-rule:evenodd; clip-rule:evenodd"
viewBox="0 0 4000 3000"

with 'width="4000" height="3000"' from 'viewBox="0 0 4000 3000"'

<svg xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2000/svg" xml:space="preserve" width="4000" height="3000" version="1.1" style="shape-rendering:geometricPrecision; text-rendering:geometricPrecision; image-rendering:optimizeQuality; fill-rule:evenodd; clip-rule:evenodd"
viewBox="0 0 4000 3000"

Postprocess:
Replace:
" M62 P0" -> ""
"M3 S1" -> "M3 S255"
"M5" -> "M3 S0"

Ordered Parts:

1x: DIY 5.5W high power 450nm Focusing Blue Laser Engraving cutting TTL 5500mW

1x10m: Hot sale 10meter GT2-6mm open timing belt width 6mm GT2 2GT Timing belt

4x: 20teeth GT2 Timing pulley 8mm

$11.33 https://www.aliexpress.com/item/*/32440196802.html

https://www.aliexpress.com/item/*/32665922113.html

comments.text:
very nice project and fantastic outcome.
I am also impressed about how clear it does the work.
What is the difference from yours and those which let big burning marks on the lasered parts? Is it the quality if the laser or distance to the object, or the used materials?
What protection googles/glasses are required for your chosen laser?
comments.author: Angel3D

comments.text:
Hello friend,
thanks for Your comment.
The expected resolution for such models are near 0,2-0,15-0,1 mm. Current version (without adjustments) provide suitable resolution of 0,2 mm ( 5 lines per millimeter ). I tryed to print a photo at 0,1 and got bad picture. But it is a first step.
This project was started in Dec,2017 and was driven mostly on weekend by myself alone so there was not a lot time for adjustment and fine tuning. Hope it is a future.
The main difference from professional laser machines are the weight. Usually the base are from the rock or huge metal plate. This allows to increase accuracy dramatically.
The distance are not really matters because i use a focusable laser and i adjust the focus by rotating external lens. I found that PWM power of "M3 S16" allows to focus it without protective goggles but they are usually on my head and i move it up for short time of adjustments.
The cheap protective goggles usually red for blue lasers that i use. And usually included in a box with laser like mine.
Meanwhile current 5.5w laser able to cut even 4mm wood - it takes about 20-30 passes with really low velocity for about 100mm/min. Usual engraving speed is 800-1000 mm/min.

description.text:
This is a 35mm fillm holder for the Epson V600. It may work on others but I have not tested on any other scanner. I process my own film and trying to get the film curl flat on the OEM holder was driving me nuts. Using this one, there is a visible improvement in focus compared to the holder I got with the scanner. Maybe that is just operator error (me). I can say that using this one speeds up my scanning considerably because I am not constantly fiddling with the film to get it flat. I printed two and have one loaded and standing by to swap out, which helps even more.
There are four parts: the main film holder, two swiveling glass clamps, and an optional corner section with the recessed square (calibration?) mirroring that section of the original film holder from Epson.The rectangular holes in the corner piece are just for saving filament and print time. I do not use the optional piece during scanning, but include it here anyway. In additional, you will need four screws for the clamps. I used short 4mm bevel headed screws. An equivalent would would be four 3/16 inch (#8) screws. I will probably buy some nylon screws to replace these, but I haven't had any problem with scratching in 20 rolls of film scanning. Make sure the screws do not protrude through the base to touch the scanner glass. You will also need a piece of glare-free glass. I got mine from betterscanning.com: http://www.betterscanning.com/scanning/insert35.htm I have no affiliation with Better Scanning, but what I have ordered from them has been excellent quality.

title: CTC E3D V6 Bowden Single Hotend
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Deutsch

English will follow beneath
Dies ist mein Extruder Halter für einen E3D V6 (oder Clone) montiert am CTC
Bis auf Luftauslass_V3 und Halter Radiallüfter werden alle Teile nur 1x benötigt.
Die Datei Luftauslass bitte in 0,15mm Layer Höhe drucken, der Rest kann in 0,2mm gedruckt werden.
Die Gewinde für den 40x40mm Hotendlüfter habe ich direkt in Halter_Oben mit der Schraube geschnitten. (Achtung: hierfür nur max 13mm Schrauben nutzen (wenn der Lüfter nicht dazwischen ist), sonst kann der Halter platzen!)

Zusätzlich benötigt werden:
6x M3x25mm Zylinderkopschrauben (30mm sollten auch noch gehen)
2-4x M3x20 (bei 10mm Hotendlüfter)
6x M3 Muttern

Als Bauteillüfter kommen diese Radiallüfter aus Israel zum Einsatz: Blower Fans

Aber Achtung! Die Lüfter Vertragen nur 5V! Ich habe sie daher an meinem Rumba Board an 12V angeschlossen und dann die Lüfter in Reihe geschaltet. Bei 24V, selbst in Reihe, werden die definitiv zerstört

Die Blower Fans habe ich nur geklebt. Bei der Montage, erst die Blower fans montieren und dann den Rest.
Die Luftauslässe können ganz zum Schluß einfach von unten eingeschoben werden.
Meine Fotos zeigen noch die Version ohne mitgedrucktem Kabelhalter, daher die "professionellen" Strapsbänder ;)

English

These are my files to mount an E3D V6 (or Clone) on a CTC
Excepts Luftauslass_V3 and Halter Radiallüfter all parts are needed only once (1x)
Pls. print Luftauslass_V3 in 0,15mm Layer height, all other files can be printed in 0,2mm Layer height.
I cutted the threads for the 40x40mm Hotend-Fan directy with a M3x13 Cylinder head screw into Halter_Oben. (Be careful and use a max. 13mm Screw, otherwise you can destroy the Halter_Oben part if you don't have the fan inbetween.

Additionally you will need:
6x M3x25mm Cylinderheadscrews (30mm should work as well)
2-4x M3x20 screws (if your hotend fan is 10mm)
6x M3 Nuts

As fans for cooling the printing, I use the fans from Israel: Blower Fans

Attention! These fans are made for 5V only! I connected them to my RUMBA Board at the 12V pin and mounted them in row, in this setup each of them gets 6V which is O.K. for them. You will defenitely destroy them if you attach them to 24V even if you solder them in row.

The Blower fans are glued to their holder. Pls. mount the blower fans to the legs first and attach the Nozzles at the final stage by just pushing them into the holes.
My photos show the first version without the cableholder attached to the Halter_Obern. Thats why you see these "professional" cable ties. ;)

CTC

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

25

Notes:
  • Die Halter für die Radiallüfter (2x) werden auf dem Rücken liegend gedruckt. Support wird benötigt
  • Luftauslass_V3 (2x) einfach stehend drucken. Kein Support
  • Oberplatte flach liegend mit dem Text Vorne lesbar drucken. Support wird benötigt.
  • Bein Rechts und Bein Links einfach auf dem Kopf stehen drucken. Kein Support.
  • Halter_Oben könnt ihr von Oben oder unten drucken. Support nötig


  • Halter Radiallüfter (2x) should be printed lying on the big plate. Support is needed
  • Luftauslass_V3 is printed (2x) standing on the big foot, use 0,15mm layer height, no support
  • Oberplatte ist printed flat lying with the text "Vorne" readable. Support needed.
  • Bein Rechts and Bein links is printed upside down, no support
  • Halter Oben is printed lying on top or base plate, support is needed

title: DPS / DP Power Supply Module Case DPS3012

description.text:
Quickly designed this case for my DPS3012 32V 12A buck adjustable DC power supply. Tried to use an existing design, bot none of them was fully met my requirements. My design goals were:

  • fully printable
  • compact
  • modular

By modular I mean replacable front / back panels for different connectors. I needed only XT60s for now, feel free to remix, add banana plugs, or a switch to the back. Included .steps to make the customization smoother.

Assembly:

After printing push M3×3 D4 knurled brass nuts into the holes of the bottom part with the help of a soldering iron at 250°C. Screw together with M3 screws.

Scale down version:

For self-contained units without a daughterboard is here.

comments.text: That wasn't a goal for me. A more than 10A PSU is quite bulky, especially when compared to the unit. I wouldn't sacrify portability by embedding one to the same enclosure. I often use this with a 24V 10A mains PSU, that has its own enclosure with some XT60 ports, I just hook this up to that. Or sometimes to a LiPo battery. More flexible this way.

title: Melzi board support frame for TronXY X1

description.text:
I was inspired to make this after I saw the Tronxy x3 control PCB cradle by Richard Baldock.

This is a Melzi Board support frame that fits inside the TronXY X1 control box.

Printer:

TronXY X1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I have provided three files.

  • The frame in one piece
  • Two piece, part 1
  • Two piece part 2

The one piece frame is too large for the X1 bed. The two piece part 1 and 2, both fit on the X1 bed together. The two pieces could be glued together, but it works just fine without glueing.

Since the X1 does not have a heated bed I printed with 5mm brim and glue stick.

I started off by printing out the design by Richard Baldock. I was hoping to use it for my Melzi board for my TronXY X1, but although the X1 and the X3 both use the same board, the control box for the X1 is smaller, thus the design by Richard did not fit. Inspired by this I proceeded to design my own version. I kept it about the same size as the Melzi board, thus would fit inside the X1 control box. I also made it a bit lower to match the height of the existing spacers so the same fixing screws could be used.

The original design clashed with the sides of the case One the first viersion I designed the board did not sit flush due to the pins of the programming and display header hitting the frame The second version had recesses to accomodate the pins.

description.text:
This is an adaptable spool holder that fits on the build plate for the TronXY X1, it is made to lock together by putting the spool post-thing upside down, to begin with so it slides into the main body, and then turn it 180 degrees so it locks in. The one in the picture is my prototype that I have adapted so i could see what I needed to change in the model, the one you print will lock in at a near 90-degree angle to the body

The point of this is to make an easy to print spool holder that fits on the bed with no tweaks and can be updated to fit different spools or bodies so the whole thing doesn't need to be printed again.

This is made to use the 2 short m5 bolts that are used for the handle to attach so no extra hardware is required.

This is the first functional print that I have uploaded in a while and I feel I have got a lot better at modeling, please post show me your prints using the made it option and give me constructive criticism, but remember i am only 15 :-)

Edit: The post has been updated for a near perfect fit, and it now allows the spool to be taken off if needed without having to disassemble the spool holder

Holder Post V8 is live, i experienced cracking of the body when trying to rotate the post to lock it, so i slimmed the key down

Pz.Kpfw X turret With 15cm L/70

Here is a simple Z axis brace for the CR-10 I modelled in Fusion 360. It mounts behind the Z axis extrusion on the right side, out of the way. I used 1/2 dia aluminum rod drilled and tapped for 1/4-20 in each end but any stiff material could be used. The easiest material to find and work with would be 1/2 inch hardwood dowel pilot drilled in the ends for wood screws. I used a 13 1/2 in long rod because I had a few on hand but a 21 inch rod would reach the top of the Z axis.
You will need 4 M4 drop in T-nuts for standard 20 MM profile extrusion, 4 M4 x 14 Socket head Capscrews and 2 low head or button head 1/4-20 screws.

T-nuts can be found here: https://www.amazon.ca/gp/product/B01DB8BJHU/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o04_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

or here: https://www.amazon.com/BQLZR-European-Standard-Aluminum-Extrusion/dp/B01KJPNE4E/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1517758894&sr=8-1&keywords=BQLZR+Silver+Carbon+Steel+Hammer+Head+Drop+In+T+Nuts+M4

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.150

Infill:

40 %

Pin/Bracket fit

The pin will be an interference fit in the bracket depending on your printer and settings.
I was able to get a snug fit by running a 31/64 reamer through the hole a few times. A drill would work - it's just a little harder to control.

comments.text:
One other thing, could you upload the F360 files, or at least STEP files, so I can fiddle with it?

title: Budget Kame - A quadruped body for SG90 servos based on Kame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a complete redesign of the popular Kame quadruped design by bq3D (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1265766).

I found some things I wanted to change about Kame's body but ended up completely redesigning it. The assembly is still based on Kame but no measurement were taken from it and parts from this design will most likely not fit onto the original Kame or vice versa.

I abandoned work on this project since I gained more knowledge on legged robots which made me completely abandon 8DOF quadrupeds. You can find all source files for Sketchup in the archive file. Feel free to do your thing. :)

Things I changed:
-Optimized for cheap SG90 servos (Kame's recess for the servo arms didn't fit and were far too large for SG90's)
-Added a battery compartment for 4x AA batteries so people don't have to invest in LiPo batteries and chargers
-Added some extra compartments and moved holes for servo cables
-Walls are thicker to contain the nuts (I didn't like them sticking out but that's personal preference)

Things I kept from the original:
-8DOF (duh)
-This is only a rework of the body, no software or electronics involved.
-It's still designed for M3 screws (round head) & (lock) nuts and F693 ZZ bearings

What I wished I added:
-Top conver you can remove without having to remove the legs
-Rework the battery compartment for 18650 cells
-Bigger measurement tolerance so less accurate 3D printers can print it without too much afterwork needed

description.text:
The Woodie Copter started off as way to make inexpensive quad frames for teaching people how to fly. As I built more of them and refined the design I began to 3D print the connecting parts. The Woodie Copter is not the coolest looking quad or the most High Tech. It is a inexpensive platform for beginners and hobbyist who want a easily repairable and replaceable frame. The frame is made from printed parts mated to 3/8 and ½ inch square sticks sold at Lowe's or any hardware store. It can easily be scaled up or down just by the length of the square sticks. The foam landing gear absorbs the abuse of learning to fly and also serve as a mounting point for the floats.

Outfitted with some LED strip the Woodie Copter has great visibility for beginners. For a fun flying LOS trainer I use 17” outer frame sticks, producing a 24” diagonal. (A 450 size quad). Flown in the “+” configuration it looks like a diamond and gives the pilot a better visual reference than a “X” quad. The “X” version is better for FPV and photography.

Both the “X” and “+” parts are included in the package. Also included are center sections for popular flight control boards such as the Eagle Tree Vector, BeeRotor, CC3D and a blank surface. Two different GPS antenna mounts are included and the Eagle Tree mount has a integrated GPS tower mount. There are also two types of center section mounts for “+” copters and fore and aft “X” center sections with and without camera mounts and transmitter mounts for FPV. A center mount for the Feyi Tech 2D GoPro gimbal is included.

Woodie Copter on floats at night.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GA-43GtFwAs

Several Woodie Copters at night with a ghost.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=07SYF85_wbU

Build thread on RC Groups.
https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2506002-Building-the-Woodie-copter&highlight=woodie

To make a "+" Copter which looks like a diamond in flight, print:
4 Woodie Corner Bracket Foam LG
2 Woodie Copter Fore and Aft Center Bracket Drop Top
2 Woodie Drop Top Corner Brace
A center section appropriate for your FC board.
Purchase 4 1/2 inch square sticks and 2 3/8 Square sticks
Piece of foam pipe insulation 1 3/4 inch OD

To make a "X" copter which looks like a square, print:
4 Woodie Corner Bracket Foam LG
2 of the Woodie X Center Brackets, FPV camera mount, TX holder and plain are included
A center section appropriate for your FC board.
Purchase 4 1/2 inch square sticks and 2 3/8 Square sticks
Piece of foam pipe insulation 1 3/4 inch OD

I use GOOP to glue the foam landing gear on. CA, wood glue or Goop for the corner brackets. The floats are a 4 inch foam ball from the craft store with a 20CC syringe cover glued into it. The foam ball must be closed cell type foam or it will get water logged. The + Copter works best on floats and is very stable. A piece of light plywood with Velcro works great for the battery holder on the bottom of the center section. The center section has standoffs with holes in it to mount the battery holder.

Printer Brand:

XYZprinting

Printer:

da Vinci Jr. 2.0 Mix

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I have a Davinci Pro, it was not on the list. I print with a raft and high supports. I use filament from ebay and it prints fine.

Make a sanding tool.

Depending on your printer, it may be necessary to clean out the square pieces where sticks go thru due to the support structure. I CA glue a piece of sand paper around a square stick one size smaller than the hole to be cleaned. Making a nice square sanding tool. This easily cleans out the square holes the sticks slide thru.

A tested and proven design.

I started making the all wood versions over 3 years ago. As more people got interested in building one I started a thread on RC Groups.

https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showthread.php?2506002-Building-the-Woodie-copter&highlight=woodie

When I got a printer I started making printed parts for the various versions and now after 2 years of re-drawing and seeing what works best I decided to publish it. Now it is self aligning and all the parts fit well. It can be glued together or screwed. It has center sections that cover mounting of most flight control boards with 28 or 31mm square mounting patterns. You can also use the plain flat center section for FC boards with a case like Naza and CC3D.

Ventilated and self-locking box for home-made TL smoothers.

What's it for?
The commonly used drv8825 driver can be missing steps resulting in "salmon skin".
A stepper smoother / TL smoother fixes this by adding resistance (in this case by the use of diodes) to the motor, smoothing out the current. I'm no electrician but this article explains it in detail and how you can make your own:
http://www.engineerination.com/2015/02/drv8825-missing-steps.html
Oops, the site seems to be down, try this instead:
https://web.archive.org/web/20171127173338/http://www.engineerination.com/2015/02/drv8825-missing-steps.html?m=1

And here is a thing you can print to test if you have the issue:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1997411

You don't have to build your own, you can buy finished smoothers online (and then you don't need this box). Just make sure that they have 8 diodes and not just 4.

Note, the box is designed to not be able to open by itself. If you close it before you are done with the mod, you may need to pry it open with a small screwdriver etc.

comments.text: It applies to 3D-printers that use "drv8825 stepper drivers". It is inserted in the motor cable. Witch motors should have one is debated but from what I can tell, most people seems to believe that the most important one is the E-motor. The linked article explains how it is installed.

description.text:
I did not want adapter on adapters to use the slim quick release on my Thrustmaster TX base, so I designed this thing that go right on the metal axle on the TX base and you screw the quick release directly to this thing and your good to go.

I printed it out in PC (polycarbonate) just to be sure that it can handle all the hard racing, but ABS should be good enough.

Remove the innerpart of the thrustmaster adapter with the 4 screws that goes into the axle, If your unlucky like me and they brake, I designed in two M5 holes on the two sides of it, you can then use a 4,2 drillbit and make holes on two of the sides, and then make M5 threads so you can use two M5 bolts to secure the new adapter thing.

Use with my slim quick release connector https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2748230
and get a coiled cable with up to 15 core's (depending on how many you need)
I used 6 for oem thrustmaster and two usb lines 4+4 and last pin for shield.

Update:
I made a new 2 part ring for the base cover, so if the screws in the axle break when taking it apart and you have to use the side screws I made hole for, you can get to them and still can take everything apart...

Cool the print with the fans at 90-100% after the first few layers, also because of the small overhang! Also make sure to use a brim to prevent the print from coming of the bed.

title: Seb's hook (for doors, walls, no visible screw)

description.text:
My wife asked for a hook to put her bathrobe up. didn't want to see the screws, so I made this guy. Tried it out, works like a charm.

You basically screw the round, peg part to the wall or door (in a stud int he wall, with the proper hardware on a door or else you'll simply rip the hook out) and then slide the hook part on that, and screw from the top to secure the cosmetic part to the peg part.

The hook should slide right on the peg, but if it's too tight (printer tolerances and what not) simply sand the little ridges down a little until it's a snug fit.

Print as is in the STL file, with support. If you print it as is, make certain you don't print too thick, as the side facing out is rounded and thicker layers would make that blocky. I did .15mm and that was ok; I'll do less for my next time.
If you want to use it for something with a lot of weight, try printing right side up with supports (turning the part as it will be when you actually use it) as the way the print will be produced will make the part stronger, and as a bonus, the front might look a little smoother.

If you like it or think it's cool, click like (come on, you know you want to!). Makes and collections and comment very welcomed.

title: Bird Birb Birdie - Sharpener and Pencil Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is Henry The Pooping Bird, he will take care of all your pencil sharpening! When the remains are digested he will leave a 100% non stinking surprise. (Optionally use a butt cap)

Fully prints without support!

He is compatible with many if not all sharpening blocks which you can insert through his butt. Don't worry, you may only need to do this procedere once.

Instead, you could of course only use it as a pencil holder or hang it up somewhere.

The Bird can be printed in full color or single color. You may paint it with any colors you desire.

The Sharpening Block Operation

First check which of the sharpening block types you want to insert and then see which fit pieces you may need to print. See the overview image below. (Any sharpener should have a sharpening block inside which you can get out, often they are just glued on)

  • First put in any Right fitting block. (In case of a big sharpening block there is non needed)
  • Then put in the sharping block in the correct direction. (Angled sharpening blocks need to be upside down)
  • Put a pencil through his mouth into the inserted sharpening block to have it in the right position. This works best when you hold the Bird upside down.
  • Insert the Left Fit Piece. On the side of the Fit Piece you will see a little overhang which will make it hold on the left side of the inside of the Bird.

If everything went well the birdie is still alive and is ready to chew on some pencils. To get it back out you might need a small plier.

Other

  • Eyes can simple put into the eye holes. Optionally little sticks can be printed and put into the back of the eyes to have them not roll around.

  • For the butt a cap can be printed, a brim or raft is recommended here

title: Goggles Case
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Goggles case that snaps shut after super-glueing in magnets.

v1.0 is for 8x3mm magnets and v1.2 is for 12x5 mm magnets. Customizable to any size using the parameters at the top of the .scad files.

Hinges are printed in so no need for a separate hinge pin.

An idea for a remix would be to sink the magnet holes into the case 1 mm or so, then split the gcode up when printing and put the magnet in before the magnet hole is covered with it's first layer.

Haven't had much luck finding out if PLA is going to dissolve in cholrine water and would appreciate any feedback in the comments as to what filament materials would be good for chlorine water and saltwater.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

I tried printing at a lower 10% infill, but was having problems with top layers not sticking. If the print layer height was too high, may begin to start having problems with the hinge. I used a 4 mm brim to improve bed adhesion.

Need to glue in the magnets. I originally used loctite to hold in neodymium 8mm x 3mm magnets, but after less than a week, the glue broke.

Recommend using weaker magnets than neodymium.

Couldn't find a large enough goggle case already existing. Also wanted built-in hinges like I have seen on 3D printed keychains.

Was able to use Minkowski sums to quickly get the rounded box shape, and then just several small modifications to get the other shapes.

The hinges are designed with a small gap between the male and female shapes similar to supports. When the male shape is first printed it will sag a little until it contacts the female shape around it at a small location. After printing, this bond is broken when rotating the case for the first time.

This is a 3D printed motor holder for material feeder. Its printed with 0.1mm layer high, 0.4 mm nozzle, PLA material, 210C hotend temperature. After a while of printing you pause the print and insert the nut in your 3D printed part. You will see when the nut hole appeare and when it is starting to close then insert nut for bowden tube.

This clip is designed to replace a broken one from an Audi A4 Avant B6 model (my vehicle, may fit others), warning triangle flap on the boot lid. There are a few designs for the inner lug that breaks on Thingiverse but I didn't find this part which I was in need of. Hopefully this creation will help others too.

Just had to use a small file to square off the back edge of the tapered clips to ensure the lug, which the clip is pushed through, could not accidentally come off. Also I had to file out the centre of the lug which I had printed off from Thingiverse, just to square it up and ensure a great fit. Nothing too strenuous, just a general tidy up. After the tidying, its a simple push fit and you're away, no more falling flaps
This was made using Microsoft's 3D builder program. I don't have much experience using the more complicated programs yet but hey, it works.

Here I designed a points motor for LGB turnouts. Other g-scale brands might work too.
It is mountable with all turnouts on both sides of course.

The assembly of the thing is quite easy:
Cleanup all the parts from errors if your printer is not that precise. At least i have to do this step...
To mount the pinion on the servo i use a hot air soldering iron to warm up the inner of the pinion and then press it on to the Servo. With this technique the outer part of the pinion won't get deformed. Alternative 1: you can try to drill the hole a tiny bit undersized and press it on the servo with Force. Alternative 2: Superglue but this can have disadvantages if you have to adjust ;-)
Then try to dry fit all the parts without the spring. They should all move freely however not too slack so they won't disengage. The two levers are screwed down with a M3x10 screw an a washer.

If everything's fine you can use some grease on all moving parts while assembling everything.
While testing, hold down the servo as it tries to move upwards and will disengage the pinion from the rack.
Maybe you end up with the mechanics only working in one direction. Then you have to adjust the pinion on the servo or move a gear tooth further.
A servo tester is quite helpful on this step.

I use quite cheap 9g servos as seen on the images to drive the mechanic. got them from amazon if you wonder.
The Spring is made from 0.7mm spring steel wire. I bend the wire of a simple tension spring with the right diameter. The length of the arms should be around 10-12mm. See the bend pattern in the images.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
Sorry Elon, I stole your flamethrower-name.

A wrist mounted device which helps you stay either cool or warm. The switch on top changes the polarity of the peltier-element inside, so the device either cools or heats you.

How it works:
The bottom of the device houses a peltier-element. When power is applied to this, its surface gets either hot or cold (depending on the polarity). By mounting this at the wrist, we take advantage of the body's circulatory system to spread the heat or cold through the body. The other side of the peltier is connected to an aluminum heatsink with a fan which blows air through it. When in cooling-mode, waste heat will get blown out of the sides of the device. When heating, cold air will be blown out. The box on the rear of the device contains electronics for supplying the appropriate voltages to the peltier-element and the fan, and also has a micro-USB socket.

Quick points:

  • Powered by micro USB.You can use common phone chargers, USB power-banks, or even a computer USB-port.
  • Low power usage: about 400mA @ 5V. Most powerbanks should be able to power this thing for hours.
  • Currently better at cooling than heating. When heating, it's trying to take heat from air at maybe 20C and put it into skin that's about 30C, which is difficult for the peltier-element. When cooling this temperature difference works to our advantage instead.

Electronics details:

  • Input voltage from Micro USB is 5V.
  • Uses an adjustable boost-converter to power a 12V fan. The fan is run at less than rated voltage to keep the fan quiet.
  • Uses an adjustable buck-converter to power the peltier-element. The peltier is run at a really low voltage, 1.7V in my case (uses about 1 to 1.5 Watts of power), to keep efficiency high, and to keep the device touch-safe.

Instructions are being made.

Warning:
Do no supply too much voltage to the peltier-element. The surface-of the peltier element might get too cold or too hot, which can result in frostbite or burns!

Suggestions, improvements or outright forks are welcome. I want this device to be as good as possible.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The "Lower electronics Box" part requires supports; all other parts can be printed without supports, as oriented. There are lots of 45 degree overhangs, and some long bridges, but it came out fine on my printer.
I recommend printing all parts with a brim.

T.E.D. Parts
  • 40x40x10mm Fan: eBay Search, Example listing
  • 40x40x20mm Heatsink: eBay Search, Example listing
  • 40x40mm peltier element (TEC1-12303): eBay Search, Example listing
  • DPDT switch (2 position): eBay Search, Example listing
  • Mini 360 DC-DC buck converter: eBay Search, Example listing
  • Micro USB breakout board: eBay Search, Example listing
  • Thermal plaster: eBay Search, Example Listing
  • Elastic band, 22mm wide: eBay Search, Example listing
  • Boost converter: eBay Search, Example listing
This is how the nameless boost converter looks. There are many different DPDT switches to be found. Mine looks like this. External parts:

Micro USB cable, preferably 1m long so you can keep the powerbank in your pocket.
And one of these:

  • USB powerbank
  • Computer with USB ports
  • Regular micro usb phone charger (wall wart)

Active temperature control

An ESP8266, a thermistor and a mosfet can be used to read the peltier temperature, and turn off the heating/cooling when the temperature gets out of safe limits. This can let us put more power through the peltier, and get a larger effect, while still keeping temperatures inside safety limits.

Better thermal interface

The flat peltier against skin does not transfer heat all that well. Perhaps some other materials can be used in between to get better heat transfer.

I have been thinking of incorporating silicone heat sink pads like this into the wristband, to spread the heating/cooling around the wrist area. This could let us run the peltier at higher power levels.

Better wearing comfort

The device is currently pretty bulky. Perhaps a custom powerbank can be made, which houses both batteries and the voltage conversion electronics. This could enable the electronics to be kept in a pocket, while only the main housing needs to be worn on the wrist.

Another option is to save about 9mm of height by using a shorter heatsink (11mm tall instead of 20mm), though this will probably lead to a lower heating/cooling effect.

There exist 7mm thick fans on eBay, so about 3mm of height can be saved by switching to these,

Larger temperature operating range

The peltier element can only create about 10-15C temperature differential in relation to the air temperature. By stacking two peltier elements on top of each other, we can reach higher or lower temperatures at the cost of higher power usage. This requires the "active temperature control" improvement to be implemented first, since we can more easily reach unsafe temperatures with two peltier elements.

Other
  • Airflow control: Something to guide the exhaust air away from the body.

Attach heat sink to peltier element

The first thing you should do is to attach the heat-sink to the peltier-element. Use the thermal plaster for this, and let it set overnight. Make sure you keep the peltier-element and heat sink aligned, as misalignment will make it hard to insert the these two parts into the main housing.

Note the direction of the fins of the heatsink in relation to where the wires of the peltier-element come out. The fins need to point out to the sides like this, so that air can flow through the two vent holes in the main housing.
The thermal plaster is a pretty strong glue when spread across two large surfaces like this; the only way you are getting the peltier-element off the heatsink again is with a hammer and chisel.

Add fan to main housing

Place the fan into the main housing, there should only be one way that this will fit. Take note of the groove for guiding the wire from the fan out of the main housing.

Add peltier-element and heat sink to main housing

Slide the heatsink and peltier-element into the main housing. There should be some resistance, but not too much. If things stop sliding at the peltier-element, be very careful, as the ceramic peltier-element might crack. If this happens it will break the circuit inside, and the peltier element will just be a useless slab of ceramic. If it's hard to insert the peltier element, it's better to take it out and use a knife to cut some plastic off the main housing to make space.

Mount lower electronics box

Slide the "lower electronics box" onto the locking slide at the back of the main housing. Keep the wires in the correct slots while doing this (wires not pictured). Solder some wires to the + and - pads on the micro USB breakout board, then glue it in place at the bottom of the electronics box.

Mount buck converter

Fit the Mini-360 buck converter into the grooves above the micro USB breakout board. Glue it in place.

Add boost converter and DPDT-switch

Solder the boost converter and DPDT-switch into the circuit, then place them somewhat like in the picture.

Mount upper electronics box

Slide the upper electronics box onto the locking slides, like with the lower part of the box. Make sure the DPDT-switch goes into its slot, and the same with the blue boost converter. This part is pretty finicky. If you are unable to get the upper electronics box all the way in place, there is probably a wire caught between the upper and lower box somewhere.

There is nothing explicitly holding the DPDT-switch up in place, however the pressure from all the wires and stuff inside the box keept it firmly in place when i built mine.

I used a hot-glue gun to put a tiny dab of glue between the two boxes. Otherwise there was a small air-gap, as there is nothing mechanically holding the two box parts together.

Circuit diagram

TODO!

  1. Solder the + and - from the micro USB board to the inputs of both DC-converters.
  2. At this point you should use a multimeter to check and adjust their outputs before connecting anything else! The blue boost converter should be set to output about 10V for now. You can adjust this voltage as you like later, depending on what noise-level you can tolerate. The tiny green buck converter should be set to output about 1.5-1.7V. Do not go above this voltage, as the peltier might cause heat/cold damage to your skin.
  3. Solder the fan wires directly to the outputs of the blue boost converter. Use the correct polarity.
  4. Solder the outputs from the green buck converter to two pins on the DPDT-switch. Solder the peltier to two other pins, and add some extra wires so that the switch reverses the polarity of the peltier when switched (TODO: Explain).

title: Repeating PaperBall-Guns   The student's gun
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These two simple toys are made to shoot simple paper projectiles, like the ones you shoot at school with an improvised blowgun.

The first one works with a piston inside, the projectile is shot by the bolt pushing it forward, this can be used to shoot rockets as well, or custom cartridges full of little paper pieces like a birdshot. (i found out that the extra barrel is decreasing the power in this gun)
The second one is operated manually using the bolt handle, and is a simple blowgun.

The first is a faster shooter, but has less range, the second is slower but more powerful.

They are both magazine-fed, using the same gravity magazine tube, they are super simple and the tolerances are not really tight, make your bullets of a specific diameter, so they'll work better, without jamming or shooting multiple balls at the same time.

Have fun!

Well, this is my fourth prototype of selective gas electrolysis machine. Works with aluminium nails in the holes, test tubes on the top, and folded aluminium sheet (a ribbon) between the nails. This should not make any rust, and should be effective.

This is a derivate of the madkite "Whistle Redesign". It's your powerful weapon in the fight against everything evil on the planet. This thing is marked as "work in progress", as it's up to us to work continuously towards a free and colorful world. Where was it originally used?
On August 2nd 2012 during a protest against the right-wing NPD event in Bayreuth, Germany. It was a huge success! Hundreds stood up against eight stick-in-the-mud NPD members. See here how they drive off after just an hour: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eUR8xVXIXRU Feel free to join the Facebook group to show your love for tolerance: https://www.facebook.com/pages/B%C3%BCndnis-KUnterBunT-BayreuthKulmbach/336403476407299

• Print it and use it wisely against any kind of intolerance, anti-democratic behavior and inhumanity.
  • I've attached a 1x scaled version as well as a bigger 1.5x scaled version (you need a strong breath for this one).
    • Printing tipps:
  • When printing pipes always go for a thick extrusion. It needs to be air-tight!
  • To ensure this: Better insert a slightly lower filament diameter in order to cheat your slicer to give you a rock solid extrusion.
  • I've printed the 1.5x version with 0.25mm layers, three 0.4 perimeters and 10% infill on my Ultimaker. Don't use support - the bridging works perfect even on the very first layer of the top. Use retraction in order to have a clean interior. If you have strings remaining remove them with a screwdriver to get better acoustics.

(This Thing is a Work-In-Progress because i didn't test-printed it yet.)

This is a remix of RichRap's MasterSpool (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2769823).
I give him the credits for this system.

I optimized a few things on it:

  • outer diameter: 195mm (optimized for 200x200mm beds)
  • holes to fix the end of the filament to the side of the spool
  • holes to screw the spool together, so it can't screw itself loose. (M6 bolts and nuts needed)
  • added level indicator

Additionally you will need 3x M6 nuts and 3x M6x45 cylinder head bolts

Except for the outer diameter (195mm), the dimensions are the same as RichRap's spool.

You need to print both parts, that the holes fit together.

I added the Fusion360-files, so you can edit it.

v2 changelog:

  • added 3 level indicators, so it looks symmetrical.
  • increased the diameter to 198mm.
  • added slots for the inner end of the filament.
  • modified the coupling system, so it can be one STL-file (thanks to @pew in the comments for the idea).

author: kawims

description.text:
I wanted to replace my common light switches with Sonoff Touch. Unfortunately the Sonoff Touch EU are too big to place them into a german double-flush-mounted box. So I decided to create a new in-wall-housing for two Sonoff Touch which is compatible to a typical german installation.

The Thing consists of three parts: The in-wall-housing, a tile and a cover.
The housing contains the high voltage part of the Sonoff Touch. The tile will be clipped onto the housing, thereupon the low-voltage part can be plugged into the high-voltage part.
You need two housings and two tiles.

At last the cover will be clipped on the two tiles, which were screwed into the flush-mounted boxes (3 x 16mm screws).
The cover is derived of a Jung AS500 design which I use on my common switches.

author: jens_k

title: MicroCube with autobed leveling function-Titan Extruder

description.text:
Thanks @Stargrove1 for this nice design. I have made lots of modifications as below:

Added nema 11 as Z axis with 8mm threaded rod.
Used a 220v 100W silicone heater as heated bed with a 2.5mm aluminum plate
Used LM8LUU for all axis (X, Y and Z)
Used aluminum rods for the bed and changed all design of the bed
Used a titan extruder and a designed a mount for it
Added autobed leveling function with an optical endstop and an 1.5 mm allen key

SOME NOTES:
X Axis Tensioner: It needs two M3 brass inserts:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/100PCS-M3-3-4-MM-Brass-Inserts-Double-Pass-Copper-Knurl-Nut-Embedded-Fastener/32825235531.html
 Z_Probe: It needs to be glued on to the X carriage where there is a special place for it. You can use CA for gluing. Also you need a 86mm tall, 1.5mm allen key or similar 1.5mm width Stainless rod. When gluing be careful about the allen key should easily pass through its hole. It works with an optical endstop. For more info about autobed function: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2551717
I have used a 220V silicon heater for the bed with an SSR. Also I have placed all the electronics under the bottom of the printer placing a 5mm wooden plate to there. Bottom plate holder is added for this reason.
 I have used a weird aluminum rod that I have found in my old stuffs as bed holder rod. Probably it is difficult to find that kind of rod. Because of this I have added a stp file for you to modify the bed structure as your demands.
Stabilizers are made with 10mm aluminum rods. You will need 110mm for shorter ones and 240mm for longer ones.
 In some parts, brass inserts were used instead of M3 Nut:
https://www.aliexpress.com/item/100PCS-M3-5-5mm-OD-5mm-Brass-Inserts-Double-Pass-Copper-Knurl-Nut-Embedded-Fastener/32822621373.html
Here is a short video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Jc38-6HCgBE

description.text:
These flat wires are typically mounted using staples inside of walls. I needed to mount some on the outside of the wall, and I need to be able to move the position of the wires on occasion.

This is a simple flat clamp with a hole for a #6 wood screw. Nothing complicated. The OpenSCAD file is included if you need to change the dimensions of the opening for a different gauge of wire.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

any

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Most slicers will print these at 100%, and I would recommend printing with that setting if your's does not. This is a thin piece by design, and the pressure of a wood screw that is sunk into wood will most definitely break any printed plastic piece if enough force is exerted, so greater infill is better (also, don't overtighten the screws).

I would print the x8 or x16 versions so you get more than one clip at a time.

Designed in OpenSCAD

Made from scratch, in code. The way all good things are made.

title: Upgraded CTC i3 Pro B 3D printer

description.text:
I changed my mk8 hotend and mk8 feeder into a e3D v6 hotend and mk9 material feeder. You can buy e3D v6 hotend on eBay, Amazon, Gearbest... from $ 10 to $20. You can download for free the mk9 material feeder and print it. The 3D printer is avelible for $154 on eBay. It is a Chinese CTC Prusa i3 Pro B 3D printer kit.
All 3D printed parts are printed on Ultimaker 2+ 3D printer. You load the 3D models into your slicer for 3D printing and chose printing parameters All 3D printed parts are printed with PLA on 0.1 mm layer high, 0.4 mm nozzle, 210C on hetend, 60C on heatbed, 30% - 50% infill and with supports. The material feeder motor holder (blue part) is printed with 100% infill and no supports.​

author: maker_101

title: modified wheel with flex tire for 1/10 rc

description.text:
I wanted to print the wheels and tires for a 4x4 Baja bug I'm working on. For me, the original wheels were just a bit too wide. I narrowed them by about %25, and I changed the outside to better fit a tire I designed.

The wheel prints with the hub support. So don’t generate supports. Once this is broken off, you will need to finish the shaft hole with a drill bit.

The tire does have a lot of little overhangs, but still prints ok. The inside lip overhang caused a lot of stringing, but since the tire will be glued to the wheel, this isn't an issue. I printed the tire with 2 perimeters and 5% infill. They are fine, and will work, but I wish I would have done 3 or 4 perimeters and 15% infill. As is, they took about 12 hours to print, but for flexible filament, I run my printer slow at 15mm/s. Obviously with more perimeters and infill, the longer the print time, but stiffer the tire.

Hope this is use full for someone.
Thanks for looking,

I made this thing to avoid egg shells in my soft-boiled morning egg.
You put the 3d printed part on top of your soft-boiled egg, lift the weight and let it go. Then the Egg Cracker cracks a nice line around the top of your egg, ready to cut off with a knife.
https://youtu.be/KymLRvwMLoo

To make this thing you need:
5mm stainless steel rod (I used a tent peg)
1 metal ball or other metal object that can be drilled through with a 5mm drill. (I used an old tire nut)
Some super glue

When the part is printed you slide the metal ball over the tent peg and glue the tent peg to the top of the printed part. There is a hole that should fitt on the top of it.

Happy Egg cracking (Topping)

title: Fan Holder 80mm for ZRIB 5.x (Zonestar P802N, P802NA)

description.text:
I adapted the fan holder from user "dark307" to work with the new ZRIB 5.x boards which support the step stick stepper drivers.
The two main changes are 9mm additional clearance between the ZRIB board and the holder to accomodate for taller heatsinks on the step sticks and lowering the fan by 9.5mm to better cover the area of the board, where the step sticks are located.

On the photos, you can clearly see that the clearance allows stepper drivers like the silent step sticks with taller heat sinks without a problem. The lowering of the fan also helps with Z homing since it adds additional clearance between the X-Axis motor and the top of the fan.
I use an Anycubic Ultrabase on my printer, which raises the Z homing position by 3.8mm, which I indicated with my calipers. However, even without the Ultrabase, there is still enough clearance for the fan holder.

Zonestar P802NA

comments.text: Actually I did get it to work. I opened the configuration.h and edited a few lines. Here's what I did... Opened https://www.repetier.com/firmware/v100/ Then set my processor and motherboard type, then skipped all the opening stuff and just went to User Interface and added my LCD "RepRapDiscount Full Graphics Smart Controller. Then on the next section "Manual Additions", I just made a comment line --> //The above is for the LCD". the // makes it a comment. Then I just downloaded the configuration.h file and compared the last section with my original which was for the 2004 5 button. Plugged in the two cables into the board, fired it up, had a couple of issues with flashing, but found that having too many languages selected was using up memory, So I just changed a lot of them from 1 to 0.

author: savf

description.text:
This is a printable replacement for the stock aluminium SC8UU bearing carriers used on many printers, including the Anet A8.

I designed these specifically for the Igus Drylin RJ4JP-01-08 replacements, but the stock LM8UUs will fit just as well. However the problem with the LM8UUs is they are designed for a much higher load than found on most printers and the ball bearings tend to slide rather than roll as they are designed to do, resulting in noise, and wear.

If you go with the Igus Drylins, there's a weight saving of ~37g over the stock SC8UU/LM8UU combination, per unit. That's nearly 150g saved on the y axis of a typical printer.

You will need 4x M4 nuts for each carrier. I used A2 stainless half nuts.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

50%

Push the bearings into the carrier from the top, don't try to slide them in lengthways. They should snap into position, but you might need to slide them a little until they fit over the locator rings.

Push the nuts into the recesses, they should be a little stiff, this is so they don't fall out when you turn them upside down. If necessary, use a screw to pull them into position.

You can find all my Anet A8 upgrades here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/FredGenius/collections/anet-a8-upgrades

I also highly recommend this Front Frame Brace by Leo Nutz:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1857991

print_settings.Notes:: This thing will probably print just fine at any resolution and infill setting.

description.text:
My wife and I have been together for a very long time. Someone found pictures of us from a few months before we met and stuck them on the fridge (don't make fun of the hair - that's the way we did it in 1990 - and yes, that's an actual Instamatic photo). The Arizona truck stop magnet that was holding them in place just wouldn't do, so I created this magnet with a heart in the middle and the words "who knew?" around it.

The phrase can be applied to any number of things people like to stick on the fridge - ultrasound pictures, wedding announcements, a good report card(!), etc. It's just cute, darn it!

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

This thing will probably print just fine at any resolution and infill setting.

Attaching the magnets

This uses 3 magnets that are 6mm in diameter and 3mm tall. Use superglue, hot glue, epoxy, or your adherent of choice to attach the magnets. These are the magnets I use:
https://www.amazon.com/Refrigerator-Magnets-Cylinder-Kitchen-Science/dp/B07873ZCY4/ref=pd_sim_79_2?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B07873ZCY4&pd_rd_r=VFHRFN8RGTZ99TTSS19S&pd_rd_w=9GaxO&pd_rd_wg=AfUad&psc=1&refRID=VFHRFN8RGTZ99TTSS19S
Rare earth magnets are very strong, and 3 is probably overkill, but I HATE it when stuff falls off the fridge because the magnets are too weak.

The openings for the magnets are a little more loose than they have to be. You can adjust that diameter in the OpenSCAD file if you prefer more of a pressure fit (as opposed to relying entirely on the integrity of the glue).

Made in OpenSCAD

I imported the heart STL file from another thing, wrapped the text around it, then added holes for magnets.

The OpenSCAD and needed STL files are included in case you want to change the text.

If you want to replicate the font that is pictured, you will need to install Open Sans from Google Fonts (https://fonts.google.com/specimen/Open+Sans)

description.text:
I haven't printed this yet, as I designed it for a friend on the Tronxy Facebook group. I've included STEP files as well in case anybody wants to tinker with the solid models.

It was designed fur use with a 40mm fan, M2.5x10mm hardware (screws/nuts) to hold the board, and M3x20mm screws and hardware to hold the halves together. If you have other fasteners or methods you'd like to use, feel free to modify the CAD files!

Also, the loops/lugs on each end allow you to zip tie the wires to the case for strain relief. It is not the most elegant solution, but it will certainly keep wires from fatiguing at the board connectors.

As always, happy printing!

EDIT (6 FEB 2018): Added a new STL for the top cover which allows the fan to be mounted inside the case. If you are OCD, you're going to hate the honeycomb grating, just sayin...

EDIT (09 FEB 2018): It fits this MOSFET.

title: Tr8x8x2 no-backlash nut for Wanhao Duplicator 7
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I don't like backlash at all. Sometimes it can be compensated easily with a careful design and construction. Some other times backlash compensation could lead to something either not useful, or even something that may generate more troubles than a good operation.
Don't really spent too much in arguing about Wanhao Duplicator 7 leading screw and nut, but having a mechanism that provides some hundreds microns play when you look for tens of microns layer height, only this alone cannot fit my engineer mind :)

So, you can find attached both the stl file that I printed and works and the OpenSCAD file to generate yours.
The issue is that you cannot find (or at least I can't in a reasonable time) any specifications for the geometry of the thread. All you know is that is 8 mm outside diameter, 8 mm pitch trapezoidal thread with 4 starts. I'm not even sure that the designation used in the filenames is correct. Anyway, it works.

It is designed to reuse the backlash nut, just as a supplementary means of prolonging the life shortage by wearing.
It is longer (40 mm) than the original one since there is enough space under the build plate bracket and there is longer thread for better guidance :)

You may use any good material for this purpose, as igus, POM (Delrin), nylon.
I started with PLA, is true a pretty performand one from Sakata3D based on Ingeo 3D870 material.

It is not yet tested for endurance, therefore this is still work in progress.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 v1

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1 mm (0.2 mm first layer)

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Print slow (e.g. 30 mm/s to allow for cooling and avoid curling of threads margins.

Just clean any elephant foot from the first layer(s).
Play a few times with the screw to "refine" it.
